[[Category:Fasciola]] [[Category:Animal diseases]] [[Category:Veterinary helminthology]] [[Category:Animals described in 1855]]

{{about|the organism|the infection|Fasciolosis}} {{Speciesbox |image = Fasciola_hepatica.JPG |image_caption = Adult ''Fasciola hepatica'' specimen |genus = Fasciola |species = hepatica |authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], 1758<ref>Linnæi, C. (1758–1759). ''Systema Naturæ per Regna Tria Naturæ, Secundum Classes, Ordines, Genera, Species, cum Haracteribus, Differentiis, Synonymis, Locis. Tomus I.'' Holmiæ: Impensis Direct. Laurentii Salvii.</ref> }}
'''''Fasciola hepatica''''', also known as the ''' common liver fluke''' or '''sheep liver fluke''', is a [[parasitism|parasitic]] trematode (fluke or [[flatworm]], a type of [[helminth]]) of the [[class (biology)|class]] [[Trematoda]], [[phylum]] [[Platyhelminthes]]. It infects the livers of various [[mammal]]s, including humans. The disease caused by the [[fluke (flatworm)|fluke]] is called [[fasciolosis]] or fascioliasis, which is a type of [[helminthiasis]] and has been classified as a [[neglected tropical disease]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Neglected Tropical Diseases|url=https://www.cdc.gov/globalhealth/ntd/diseases/index.html|website=cdc.gov|accessdate=28 November 2014|date=June 6, 2011}}</ref> [[Fasciolosis]] is currently classified as a plant/food-borne [[trematode]] infection, often acquired through eating the parasite's [[Trematode life cycle stages|metacercariae]] encysted on plants.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mas-Coma | first1 = S | last2 = Bargues | first2 = MD | last3 = Valero | first3 = MA | date = 2005 | title = Fascioliasis and other plant-borne trematode zoonoses | url = | journal = International Journal for Parasitology | volume = 35 | issue = 11 | pages = 1255–1278 | doi = 10.1016/j.ijpara.2005.07.010 | pmid=16150452}}</ref> ''F. hepatica'', which is distributed worldwide, has been known as an important parasite of sheep and cattle for decades and causes significant economic losses in these livestock species, up to £23 million in the UK alone.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nadis.org.uk/bulletins/liver-fluke-control-in-cattle.aspx|title=NADIS - National Animal Disease Information Service -|website=www.nadis.org.uk|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref> Because of its relatively large size and economic importance, it has been the subject of many scientific investigations and may be the best-known of any trematode species. ''F. hepatica's'' closest relative is ''[[Fasciola gigantica]]''. These two [[Fluke (flatworm)|flukes]] are sister species; they share many [[Morphology (biology)|morphological features]] and can mate with each other.<ref name="Mas‐ComaValero2009">{{Cite book|last1=Mas‐Coma|first1=Santiago|last2=Valero|first2=María Adela|last3=Bargues|first3=María Dolores|title=Chapter 2 Fasciola, Lymnaeids and Human Fascioliasis, with a Global Overview on Disease Transmission, Epidemiology, Evolutionary Genetics, Molecular Epidemiology and Control|volume=69|year=2009|pages=41–146|issn=0065-308X|doi=10.1016/S0065-308X(09)69002-3|pmid=19622408|journal=Advances in Parasitology|isbn=9780123747952}}</ref>
== Life cycle == [[File:Galba truncatula shell.png|thumb|''[[Galba truncatula]]'', an amphibious freshwater [[Lymnaeidae|lymnaeid snail]] that serves as the main intermediate host of ''Fasciola hepatica'' in Europe]] [[File:Fasciola LifeCycle 2013.png|thumb|The lifecycle of ''Fasciola hepatica'']]
''Fasciola hepatica'' occurs in the liver of a [[definitive host]] and its lifecycle is indirect. Definitive hosts of the fluke are [[cattle]], [[sheep]], and [[African Buffalo|buffalo]]es. Wild [[ruminant]]s and other mammals, including humans, can act as definitive hosts as well.<ref name="torgerson_claxton">{{cite book |last= Torgerson |first=P |author2= Claxton JR |chapter=Epidemiology and Control |editor=Dalton, JP |title=Fasciolosis |publisher=CABI Pub |location=Wallingford, Oxon, UK |year=1999 |pages=113–149 |isbn=978-0-85199-260-0 }}</ref> The life cycle of ''F. hepatica'' goes through the [[intermediate host]] and several environmental larval stages.<ref name="andrews">{{cite book |last= Andrews |first=JS |chapter= Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica |editor=Dalton, JP |title=Fasciolosis |publisher=CABI Pub |location=Wallingford, Oxon, UK |year=1999 |pages=1–30 |isbn=978-0-85199-260-0 }}</ref> Intermediate hosts of ''F. hepatica'' are air-breathing freshwater snails from the family [[Lymnaeidae]]. Although several lymnaeid species susceptible to ''F. hepatica'' have been described, the parasite develops only in one or two major species on each continent. ''[[Galba truncatula]]'' is the main snail host in Europe, partly in Asia, Africa, and South America. ''[[Lymnaea viatrix|Lymnaea viator]]'', ''[[Lymnaea neotropica|L. neotropica]]'', ''[[Pseudosuccinea columella]]'', and ''[[Lymnaea cubensis|L. cubensis]]'' are most common intermediate hosts in Central and South America.<ref name="Mas‐ComaValero2009" /><ref name="torgerson_claxton" /> Several other lymnaeid snails may be naturally or experimentally infected with ''F. hepatica'', but their role in transmission of the fluke is low.<ref name="Mas‐ComaValero2009" /> The list of lymnaeid snails that may serve as natural or experimental intermediate hosts of ''F. hepatica'' include:<ref name="Correa 2010">{{cite journal | last1 = Correa | first1 = C. A. | last2 = Escobar | first2 = J. S. | last3 = Durand | first3 = P. | last4 = Renaud | first4 = F. | last5 = David | first5 = P. | last6 = Jarne | first6 = P. | last7 = Pointier | first7 = J.-P. | last8 = Hurtrez-Boussès | first8 = S. | year = 2010 | title = Bridging gaps in the molecular phylogeny of the Lymnaeidae (Gastropoda: Pulmonata), vectors of Fascioliasis | url = | journal = [[BMC Evolutionary Biology]] | volume = 10 | issue = | page = 381 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-10-381 | pmid=21143890 | pmc=3013105}}</ref>
* ''[[Austropeplea ollula]]'' * ''[[Austropeplea tomentosa]]'' * ''[[Austropeplea viridis]]'' * ''[[Fossaria bulimoides]]'' * ''[[Galba truncatula]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea cousini]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea cubensis]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea diaphana]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea humilis]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea neotropica]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea occulta]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea stagnalis]]'' * ''[[Lymnaea viatrix]]'' * ''[[Omphiscola glabra]]'' * ''[[Pseudosuccinea columella]]'' * ''[[Radix auricularia]]'' * ''[[Radix lagotis]]'' * ''[[Radix natalensis]]'' * ''[[Radix peregra]]'' * ''[[Radix rubiginosa]]'' * ''[[Stagnicola caperata]]'' * ''[[Stagnicola fuscus]]'' * ''[[Stagnicola palustris]]'' * ''[[Stagnicola turricula]]''
The [[metacercariae]] are released from the [[freshwater snail]] as [[cercariae]], and form cysts on various surfaces including [[Aquatic plant|aquatic vegetation]]. The [[mammal]]ian host then eats this vegetation and can become infected. Humans can often acquire these infections through eating freshwater [[plants]] such as [[watercress]]. Inside the [[duodenum]] of the [[mammal]]ian host, the [[metacercariae]] are released from within their cysts. From the [[duodenum]], they burrow through the lining of the [[intestine]] and into the [[peritoneal cavity]]. They then migrate through the [[intestine]]s and [[liver]], and into the [[bile ducts]]. Inside the [[bile ducts]], they develop into an adult [[Trematoda|fluke]].<ref name="CDCfascioliasis">{{cite web|title=Parasites – Fascioliasis (Fasciola Infection)|url= https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/fasciola/biology.html |website=cdc.gov|accessdate=12 March 2016|date=January 10, 2013}}</ref> In humans, the time taken for ''F. hepatica'' to mature from [[metacercariae]] into an adult [[Trematoda|fluke]] is roughly 3 to 4 months. The adult [[Trematoda|flukes]] can then produce up to 25,000 eggs per [[Trematoda|fluke]] per day.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Valero | first1 = MA | last2 = Panova | first2 = M | last3 = Comes | first3 = AM | last4 = Fons | first4 = R | last5 = Mas-Coma | first5 = S | date = 2002 | title = Patterns in size and shedding of Fasciola hepatica eggs by naturally and experimentally infected murid rodents | url = | journal = Journal of Parasitology | volume = 88 | issue = 2 | pages = 308–313 | doi=10.1645/0022-3395(2002)088[0308:PISASO]2.0.CO;2| hdl = 10550/16781 }}</ref> These eggs are passed out via [[Feces|stools]] and into freshwater. Once in freshwater, the eggs become [[embryonated]], allowing them to hatch as [[miracidia]], which then find a suitable intermediate snail host of the [[Lymnaeidae]] family. Inside this snail, the [[miracidia]] develop into [[Trematode lifecycle stages|sporocysts]], then to [[Trematode life cycle stages|rediae]], then to [[cercariae]]. The [[cercariae]] are released from the snail to form [[metacercariae]] and the life cycle begins again.<ref name="CDCfascioliasis"/>
== Morphology and anatomy == ''Fasciola hepatica'' is one of the largest [[fluke (flatworm)|fluke]]s of the world, reaching a length of 30 mm and a width of 13 mm (''[[Fasciola gigantica]]'', though, is even bigger and can reach up to 75 mm).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/fasciola/biology.html|title=CDC - Fasciola - Biology|last=Prevention|first=CDC - Centers for Disease Control and|website=www.cdc.gov|language=en-us|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref> It is leaf-shaped, pointed at the back (posteriorly), and wide in the front (anteriorly). The [[Sucker (parasitic worm anatomy)|oral sucker]] is small but powerful and is located at the end of a cone-shape projection at the anterior end. The [[Acetabulum (morphology)|acetabulum]] is a larger sucker than the oral sucker and is located at the anterior end.<ref name="CDCfascioliasis"/>
[[File:Syncytial epithelia.jpg|thumb|A simple diagram to show the difference between the teguments of free-living and parasitic flatworms: a. shows the syncytial epithelial tegument found in parasitic flatworms, such as ''F. hepatica''. b. shows the multicellular, nonsyncytial, epithelia, found in nonparasitic, free-living flatworms.]]
===Tegument=== The outer surface of the [[fluke (flatworm)|fluke]] is called the [[Tegument (helminth)|tegument]]. This is composed of [[scleroprotein]], and its primary function is to protect the [[fluke (flatworm)|fluke]] from the destructive [[Human digestive system|digestive system]] of the host.<ref name="BilsMartin1966">{{cite journal|last1=Bils|first1=R. F.|last2=Martin|first2=W. E.|title=Fine Structure and Development of the Trematode Integument|journal=Transactions of the American Microscopical Society|volume=85|issue=1|year=1966|pages=78|issn=0003-0023|doi=10.2307/3224777|jstor=3224777}}</ref> Its also used for renewal of the surface plasma membrane and the active uptake of nutrients.<ref name="WilsonWright2011">{{cite journal|last1=Wilson|first1=R. Alan|last2=Wright|first2=Janelle M.|last3=de Castro-Borges|first3=William|last4=Parker-Manuel|first4=Sophie J.|last5=Dowle|first5=Adam A.|last6=Ashton|first6=Peter D.|last7=Young|first7=Neil D.|last8=Gasser|first8=Robin B.|last9=Spithill|first9=Terry W.|title=Exploring the ''Fasciola hepatica'' tegument proteome|journal=International Journal for Parasitology|volume=41|issue=13–14|year=2011|pages=1347–1359|issn=0020-7519|doi=10.1016/j.ijpara.2011.08.003|pmid=22019596}}</ref> On the surface of the tegument are also small spines. Initially, these spines are single-pointed, then, just prior to the fluke entering the [[bile ducts]], they become multipointed. At the anterior end of the [[fluke (flatworm)|fluke]], the spines have between 10 and 15 points, whereas at the posterior end, they have up to 30 points.<ref name="Bennett1975">{{cite journal|last1=Bennett|first1=Clive E.|title=Scanning Electron Microscopy of ''Fasciola hepatica'' L. during Growth and Maturation in the Mouse|journal=The Journal of Parasitology|volume=61|issue=5|year=1975|pages=892–8|issn=0022-3395|doi=10.2307/3279230|pmid=1185431|jstor=3279230}}</ref> The [[Tegument (helminth)|tegument]] is a [[syncytium|syncytial epithelium]]. This means it is made from the fusion of many cells, each containing one [[Cell nucleus|nucleus]], to produce a [[multinucleated cell]] membrane. In the case of ''F. hepatica'', no [[Cell nucleus|nuclei]] are in the outer cytoplasm between the basal and apical membranes. Thus, this region is referred to as anucleate. Instead, the nuclei are found in the cell bodies, also known as tegumental cells, these connect to the outer cytoplasm via thin [[cytoplasm|cytoplasmic strands]]. The tegumental cells contain the usual cytoplasmic organelles ([[mitochondria]], [[Golgi bodies]], and [[endoplasmic reticulum]]).<ref name="Southgate2009">{{cite journal|last1=Southgate|first1=V. R.|title=Observations on the epidermis of the miracidium and on the formation of the tegument of the sporocyst of Fasciola hepatica|journal=Parasitology|volume=61|issue=2|year=2009|pages=177–90|issn=0031-1820|doi=10.1017/S0031182000040993|pmid=5483910}}</ref> The tegument plays a key role in the fluke’s infection of the host. Studies have shown that certain parts of the tegument (in this case, the [[antigen]] named Teg) can actually suppress the [[Immune system|immune response]] of the [[mammal]]ian host. This means that the fluke is able to weaken the [[Immune system|immune response]], and increase its chances of a successful infection. A successful infection is needed for the fluke to have enough time to develop into an adult and continue its lifecycle.<ref name="HamiltonDowling2009">{{cite journal|last1=Hamilton|first1=C. M.|last2=Dowling|first2=D. J.|last3=Loscher|first3=C. E.|last4=Morphew|first4=R. M.|last5=Brophy|first5=P. M.|last6=O'Neill|first6=S. M.|title=The Fasciola hepatica Tegumental Antigen Suppresses Dendritic Cell Maturation and Function|journal=Infection and Immunity|volume=77|issue=6|year=2009|pages=2488–2498|issn=0019-9567|doi=10.1128/IAI.00919-08|pmid=19332532|pmc=2687350}}</ref>
===Digestive system=== [[File:Image from page 174 of "Introduction to zoology; a guide to the study of animals, for the use of secondary schools;" (1900) (14598306110).jpg|thumb|Image showing the location of the mouth, labelled ''mo'', and the anterior sucker, as labelled ''sckr'']]
The alimentary canal of ''F. hepatica'' has a single mouth which leads into the [[Gastrovascular cavity|blind gut]]; it has no [[anus]]. The mouth is located within the anterior [[Sucker (zoology)|sucker]] on the [[ventral side]] of the fluke. This mouth leads to the [[pharynx]], which is then followed by a narrow [[oesophagus]]. The oesophagus, which is lined with a thin layer of [[epithelial cells]], then opens up into the [[large intestine]]. As no anus is present, the intestine branches, with each branch ending blindly near the posterior end of the body.<ref name="Kotpal2012">{{cite book |last=Kotpal|first=RL|date=2012 |title=Modern Text Book of Zoology: Invertebrates |url=https://books.google.com/?id=JuuWlZ7Llb8C&dq=fasciola+hepatica+digestive+system |location=New Delhi |publisher=Rastogi Publications |page=338 |isbn=978-81-7133-903-7}}</ref> Flukes migrate into smaller [[capillaries]] and [[bile ducts]] when feeding within the host. They use their mouth [[Sucker (zoology)|suckers]] to pull off and suck up food, [[bile]], [[lymph]], and tissue pieces from the walls of the bile ducts.<ref name="Kotpal2012"/> ''F. hepatica'' relies on [[extracellular digestion]] which occurs within the [[intestine]] of the host. The waste materials are [[defecation|egested]] through the mouth. The nonwaste matter is [[adsorption|adsorbed]] back in through the tegument and the general surface of the fluke. The tegument facilitates this adsorption by containing many small folds to increase the surface area.<ref name="Kotpal2012"/>
===Respiratory system=== [[File:Animal biology (1938) (17576890133).jpg|thumb|Diagram of the main organ systems of ''F. hepatica'' throughout the progressive life stages of the fluke (1938). ''A'' - egg; ''B'' - miracidium; ''C'' - sporocyst; ''D'' - rediae, ''E'' - immature cercaria, ''F'' - cercaria, ''G'' - encysted stage, ''H'' - adult fluke (nervous and reproductive systems omitted)]] ''F. hepatica'' has no [[respiratory organs]]: the adult flukes respire [[Anaerobic respiration|anaerobically]] (without oxygen). [[Glycogen]] taken from within the host is broken down by [[glycolysis]] to produce [[carbon dioxide]] and [[fatty acids]]. This process provides the fluke with energy.<ref name="Bhatnagar2008">{{cite book |last1=Bhatnagar|first1=MC|last2=Bansal|first2=G|date=2009 |title=Non-Chordata |url=https://books.google.com/?id=FPhfjyfr2OcC&dq=fasciola+hepatica+respiratory+system|location=Delhi |publisher=Krishna Prakashan Media|pages=153–154 |isbn=978-81-8283-036-3}}</ref> In contrast, the free-living [[miracidia]] stages of the parasite generally develop within oxygen-rich environments. The free-living stages of the parasite are thought to respire [[aerobic respiration|aerobically]], to gain the most energy from their environment.<ref name="BoyunagaSchmitz2002">{{cite journal|last1=Boyunaga|first1=H.|last2=Schmitz|first2=M.G.J.|last3=Brouwers|first3=J.F.H.M.|last4=Van Hellemond|first4=J.J.|last5=Tielens|first5=A.G.M.|title=Fasciola hepatica miracidia are dependent on respiration and endogenous glycogen degradation for their energy generation|journal=Parasitology|volume=122|issue=2|year=2002|issn=0031-1820|doi=10.1017/S0031182001007211}}</ref>
===Excretory system=== ''F. hepatica's'' [[excretory system]] contains a network of [[tubule]]s surrounding one main [[excretory system|excretory canal]]. This canal leads to the [[excretory system|excretory pore]] at the posterior end of the fluke. This main canal branches into four sections within the dorsal and ventral regions of the body. The role of ''F. hepatica's'' excretory system is [[excretion]] and [[osmoregulation]].<ref name="Bhatnagar2008"/> Each tubule within the [[excretory system]] is connected to a [[flame cell]], otherwise known as [[nephridium|protonephridia]]. These cells are modified [[parenchyme]] cells. In ''F. hepatica'', their role is to perform excretion, but more importantly, osmoregulatory functions. [[Flame cell]]s are therefore primarily used to remove excess water.<ref name="Bhatnagar2008"/>
===Nervous system and sensory organs=== The nerve system of ''F. hepatica'' consists of a pair of [[Ganglion|nerve ganglia]], each one is located on either side of the [[oesophagus]]. Around the oesophagus is a [[Nerve net|nerve ring]], which connects the two [[Ganglion|nerve ganglia]] together. The nerves stem from this ring, reaching the posterior end of the body. At the posterior end, one pair of nerves becomes thicker than the others; these are known as the lateral nerve cords. From these lateral nerve cords, the other nerves branch. Sensory organs are absent from ''F. hepatica''.<ref name="Puranik2007">{{cite book |last1=Puranik|first1=P|last2=Bhate|first2=A|date=2007 |title=Animal Forms And Functions: Invertebrata |url=https://books.google.com/?id=-kdq6RyyVE0C&dq=fasciola+hepatica+nervous+system|location=New Delhi |publisher=Sarup & Sons|pages=172–175 |isbn=978-81-7625-791-6}}</ref><ref name="MandalFB2012">{{cite book |last=Mandal|first=P|last2=F.B.|date =2012 |title=Invertebrate Zoology |url=https://books.google.com/?id=kwa6_L6vlpkC&pg=PA11&dq=fasciola+hepatica+nervous+system#v=onepage&q=fasciola%20hepatica%20nervous%20system&f=false |location=Delhi |publisher=PHI Learning|isbn=978-81-203-4615-4}}</ref>
===Reproductive system=== ''F. hepatica'' adult flukes are [[hermaphrodite]]; each contains both male and female [[reproductive organs]]. The male and female reproductive organs open up into the same chamber within the body, which is called the [[genital]] atrium. The genital atrium is an [[ectoderm]]al sac which opens up to the outside of the fluke via a [[Gonopore|genital pore]].<ref name="Puranik2007"/> The [[testes]] are formed of two branched tubules, these are located in the middle and posterior regions of the body. From the [[epithelium]] lining of the tubules, [[sperm]] is produced. The sperm then passes into the [[vas deferens]] and then into the [[seminal vesicle]]. From the [[seminal vesicle]] projects the [[ejaculatory duct]], and this opens into the genital atrium, and many [[prostate]] glands surround this opening.<ref name="Puranik2007"/> The right side of the anterior [[testis]] has a branched, tubular [[ovary]]. From here, a short [[oviduct]] passes to the [[vitelline duct]]. This duct connects, via a junction, the ovaries, the [[uterus]], and the yolk reservoir. From this junction, the uterus opens into the [[genital]] atrium; this opening is surrounded by [[Mehlis gland]]s. In some flukes, the terminal end of the uterus is strengthened with [[muscles]] and [[Spine (zoology)|spines]].<ref name="Puranik2007"/>
''F. hepatica'' reproduces both sexually, via the [[hermaphrodite]] adult flukes, and [[Asexual reproduction|asexually]]. The [[miracidia]] can reproduce asexually within the intermediate [[Lymnaea|snail]] host.<ref name="Hurtrez-BoussèsMeunier2001">{{cite journal|last1=Hurtrez-Boussès|first1=Sylvie|last2=Meunier|first2=Cécile|last3=Durand|first3=Patrick|last4=Renaud|first4=François|title=Dynamics of host–parasite interactions: the example of population biology of the liver fluke (Fasciola hepatica)|journal=Microbes and Infection|volume=3|issue=10|year=2001|pages=841–849|issn=1286-4579|doi=10.1016/S1286-4579(01)01442-3}}</ref>
==Prevalence== [[File:Fasciola hepatica prevalence.jpg|left|thumb|Fasciola hepatica prevalence. The countries in red are those with high prevalence, those in orange have low-medium prevalence.<ref name="Cywińska2005"/><ref name="Tolan2011"/><ref name="McManusDalton2007"/><ref name="Mas-ComaMas-Coma2005">{{cite journal|last1=Mas-Coma|first1=S.|last2=Mas-Coma|first2=S.|title=Epidemiology of fascioliasis in human endemic areas|journal=Journal of Helminthology|volume=79|issue=3|year=2005|pages=207–216|issn=0022-149X|doi=10.1079/JOH2005296}}</ref>]] Currently, ''F. hepatica'' has one of the widest geographical spread of any parasitic and vector-borne disease. Originating in Europe, it has expanded to colonize over 50 countries, covering all continents except [[Antarctica]].<ref name="Cywińska2005"> {{Cite journal | author=Cywińska A | title=Epidemiology of fascioliasis in human endemic areas | journal=Journal of Helminthology | volume=79 | issue=3 | year=2005 | pages=207–216 | doi=10.1079/JOH2005296}} </ref> In contrast, ''[[Fasciola gigantica|F. gigantica]]'' is generally considered more geographically restricted to the tropical regions of [[Africa]], [[Asia]], and the [[Middle East]], with some overlap between the two species.<ref name="Tolan2011"> {{Cite journal | author=Tolan RW | title=Fascioliasis due to Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica infection: an update on this 'neglected'neglected tropical disease | journal=Laboratory Medicine | volume=42 | issue=2 | year=2011 | pages=107–116 | doi=10.1309/LMLFBB8PW4SA0YJI }} </ref>
[[Climate]] affects both ''F. hepatica'' and its [[intermediate host]], the snail. For example, the development of ''F. hepatica'' miracidia and larvae, and the reproduction of ''[[Galba truncatula]]'', require a temperature range of 10 to 25 °C. In addition, they both require high levels of moisture in the air, as both are at risk of [[desiccation]]. Due to this, the [[prevalence]], along with the intensity of infection, of ''F. hepatica'' is primarily dependent on rainfall levels and temperature.<ref name="Cywińska2005"/>
==Parasitic adaptations== [[File:PSM V23 D765 Free cercaria in water and cysts attached to the grass.jpg|thumb|The left image shows the free-swimming cercariae, the flagella is clearly visible. The right side of the diagram shows the cysts attached to grass.]] ''F. hepatica’s'' [[tegument (helminth)|tegument]] protects it from the [[enzyme]]s of the host's [[stomach]], whilst still allowing water to pass through.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Smyth|first1=JD|last2=Halton|first2=DW|title=The physiology of trematodes |url=https://books.google.com/?id=WyM4AAAAIAAJ&dq=fasciola+hepatica+tegument+water+permeable |location=England |publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=23|isbn=978-0-521-22283-9|date=1983-12-29}}</ref> Free-swimming larvae have [[cilia]] and the [[cercariae]] have a flagellum-like tail to help them swim through the aquatic environment and also allow them to reach the plants on which they form a cyst.<ref name="McManusDalton2007">{{cite journal|last1=McManus|first1=DP|last2=Dalton|first2=JP|title=Vaccines against the zoonotic trematodes Schistosoma japonicum, Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica|journal=Parasitology|volume=133|issue=S2|year=2007|pages=S43-61|issn=0031-1820|doi=10.1017/S0031182006001806|pmid=17274848|hdl=10453/15032}}</ref> To attach within the host, ''F. hepatica'' has oral [[Sucker (zoology)|suckers]] and body spines. Their pharynges also help them to suck onto the tissues within the body, particularly within the [[bile duct]]s.<ref name="HalfertyBrennan2008">{{cite journal|last1=Halferty|first1=L|last2=Brennan|first2=GP|last3=Hanna|first3=REB|last4=Edgar|first4=HW|last5=Meaney|first5=MM|last6=McConville|first6=M|last7=Trudgett|first7=A|last8=Hoey|first8=L|last9=Fairweather|first9=I|title=Tegumental surface changes in juvenile Fasciola hepatica in response to treatment in vivo with triclabendazole|journal=Veterinary Parasitology|volume=155|issue=1–2|year=2008|pages=49–58|issn=0304-4017|doi=10.1016/j.vetpar.2008.04.011|pmid=18511199}}</ref> The adult fluke's respiration is anaerobic; this is ideal, as no [[oxygen]] is available in the [[liver]].<ref name="Bhatnagar2008"/> ''F. hepatica'' is adapted to produce a large number of eggs, which increases its chances of survival, as many eggs are destroyed on release into the environment. Also, ''F. hepatica'' is [[hermaphrodite]], thus all flukes can produce eggs, increasing the number of offspring produced by the population.<ref name="Puranik2007"/>
[http://parasite.wormbase.org/Fasciola_hepatica_prjeb6687/Info/Index/ The genome for ''F. hepatica''] was published in 2015. At 1.3 Gb, its genome is one of the largest known [[pathogen]] [[genome]]s. The genome contains many [[Polymorphism (biology)|polymorphisms]], and this represents the potential for the fluke to evolve and rapidly [[Adaptation|adapt]] to changes in the environment, such as host availability and drug or [[vaccine]] interventions.<ref name="CwiklinskiDalton2015">{{cite journal|last1=Cwiklinski|first1=Krystyna|last2=Dalton|first2=John Pius|last3=Dufresne|first3=Philippe J|last4=La Course|first4=James|last5=Williams|first5=Diana JL|last6=Hodgkinson|first6=Jane|last7=Paterson|first7=Steve|title=The Fasciola hepatica genome: gene duplication and polymorphism reveals adaptation to the host environment and the capacity for rapid evolution|journal=Genome Biology|volume=16|issue=1|pages=71|year=2015|issn=1465-6906|doi=10.1186/s13059-015-0632-2|pmid=25887684|pmc=4404566}}</ref>
== Epidemiology == ''For more information on the epidemiology – see the disease page, [[fasciolosis]]''
Infection begins when cyst-covered aquatic vegetation is eaten or when water containing metacercariae is drunk. In the [[United Kingdom]], ''F. hepatica'' frequently causes disease in [[ruminants]], most commonly between March and December.<ref name=gorgasmarch/>
Humans become infected by eating [[watercress]] or by drinking 'Emoliente', a Peruvian drink that uses drops of watercress juice. Cattle and sheep are infected when they consume the infectious stage of the parasite from low-lying, marshy [[pasture]].<ref name=gorgasmarch>{{cite web|title=Gorgas Case 5 - 2015 Series|url=http://www.uab.edu/medicine/gorgas/cases-blog|website=The Gorgas Course in Clinical Tropical Medicine|publisher=University of Alabama|accessdate=10 March 2015|date=2 March 2015}}</ref>
Human infections have been reported from more than 75 countries around the world. In Asia and Africa, people are infected both by ''F. hepatica'' and ''F. gigantica'' whereas human fasciolosis is caused only by ''F. hepatica'' in South and Central America and Europe.<ref>http://www.who.int/foodborne_trematode_infections/fascioliasis/fascioliasis_epidemiology/en/</ref>
The presence of ''F. hepatica'' can interfere with the detection of [[bovine tuberculosis]] in cattle. Cattle co-infected with ''F. hepatica'', compared to those infected with ''M. bovis'' alone, react weakly to the single intradermal comparative cervical tuberculin (SICCT) test.<ref>[http://ahvla.defra.gov.uk/External_OV_Instructions/TB_Instructions/Skin_Test/index.htm single intradermal comparative cervical tuberculin (SICCT) test]</ref> Therefore, an infection from ''F. hepatica'' can make it difficult to detect [[bovine tuberculosis]], this is, of course, a major problem in the farming industry.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Claridge|first1=Jen|last2=Diggle|first2=Peter|last3=McCann|first3=Catherine M.|last4=Mulcahy|first4=Grace|last5=Flynn|first5=Rob|last6=McNair|first6=Jim|last7=Strain|first7=Sam|last8=Welsh|first8=Michael|last9=Baylis|first9=Matthew|last10=Williams|first10=Diana J.L.| title=Fasciola hepatica is associated with the failure to detect bovine tuberculosis in dairy cattle| journal=Nature Communications| date=2012|volume=3|pages=853| doi=10.1038/ncomms1840|url=http://www.nature.com/ncomms/journal/v3/n5/full/ncomms1840.html|access-date=2015-09-15| pmid=22617293| pmc=3989536}}</ref>
== Fasciolosis == {{Main|Fasciolosis}} [[Image:Fasciola hepatica2.jpg|thumb|250px|Slide showing ''Fasciola hepatica's'' internal organs]] Both ''F. hepatica'' and ''F. gigantica'' can cause fasciolosis. Human symptoms vary depending on whether the disease is chronic or acute. During the acute phase, the immature worms begin penetrating the gut, causing symptoms of fever, nausea, swollen liver, skin rashes, and extreme abdominal pain.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/foodborne_trematode_infections/fascioliasis/en/|title=WHO {{!}} Fascioliasis|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref> The chronic phase occurs when the worms mature in the bile duct, and can cause symptoms of intermittent pain, jaundice, and anemia.<ref name=":1" /> In cattle and sheep, classic signs of fasciolosis include persistent diarrhea, chronic weight loss, anemia, and reduced milk production.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hccmpw.org.uk/medialibrary/pdf/1377.pdf|title=Fascioliasis (liver fluke) in cattle|last=Scott|first=Phil|date=|website=NADIS Health Bulletin|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-30}}</ref> Some remain asymptomatic. ''F. hepatica'' can cause sudden death in both sheep and cattle, due to internal hemorrhaging and liver damage.<ref name=":0" />
[[Fasciolosis]] is an important cause of both production and economic losses in the dairy and meat industries. Over the years, the prevalence has increased and it is likely to continue increasing in the future.<ref name="HowellBaylis2015">{{cite journal|last1=Howell|first1=Alison|last2=Baylis|first2=Matthew|last3=Smith|first3=Rob|last4=Pinchbeck|first4=Gina|last5=Williams|first5=Diana|title=Epidemiology and impact of Fasciola hepatica exposure in high-yielding dairy herds|journal=Preventive Veterinary Medicine|volume=121|issue=1–2|year=2015|pages=41–48|issn=0167-5877|doi=10.1016/j.prevetmed.2015.05.013|pmid=26093971|pmc=4528078}}</ref> Livestock are often treated with flukicides, chemicals toxic to flukes, including [[bromofenofos]],<ref>{{Cite book | title = Saunders Comprehensive Veterinary Dictionary | author = Virginia P. Studdert, Clive C. Gay, Douglas C. Blood | publisher = Elsevier Health Sciences | date = 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | title = Veterinary Pharmacology and Toxicology | editor = Y. Ruckebusch, P.-L. Toutian, G.D. Koritz | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media | date = 2012 | page = 762}}</ref> [[triclabendazole]], and [[bithionol]]. [[Ivermectin]], which is widely used for many [[helminth]]ic parasites, has low effectivity against ''F. hepatica'', as does [[praziquantel]].<ref name="SibilleCalléja2000">{{cite journal|last1=Sibille|first1=Pierre|last2=Calléja|first2=Cécile|last3=Carreras|first3=Florence|last4=Bigot|first4=Karine|last5=Galtier|first5=Pierre|last6=Boulard|first6=Chantal|title=Fasciola hepatica: Influence of Gender and Liver Biotransformations on Flukicide Treatment Efficacy of Rats Infested and Cured with Either Clorsulon/Ivermectin or Triclabendazole|journal=Experimental Parasitology|volume=94|issue=4|year=2000|pages=227–237|issn=0014-4894|doi=10.1006/expr.2000.4501|pmid=10831390}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Ortega|first1=YR| title=Foodborne Parasites |url=https://books.google.com/?id=92pNSYcQl8sC&dq=bithional+for+fasciola+hepatica|location=Georgia, USA |publisher=Springer|page=186|isbn=978-0387-30068-9|date=2006-11-22}}</ref> For humans, the type of control depends on the setting. One important method is through the strict control over the growth and sales of edible water plants such as [[watercress]]. This is particularly important in highly [[Endemic (epidemiology)|endemic]] areas. Some farms are [[Irrigation|irrigated]] with [[Pollution|polluted]] water, hence, [[vegetables]] farmed from such land should be thoroughly washed and cooked before being eaten.<ref name="CDCfascioliasis" />
The best way to prevent [[fasciolosis]] is by reducing the lymnaeid snail population or separating livestock from areas with these snails.<ref name=":2" /> These two methods are not always the most practical, so control by treating the herd before they are potentially infected is commonly practiced.
==Diagnosis== [[File:Egg of Fasciola hepatica 08G0041 lores.jpg|thumb|''F. hepatica'' egg in stool sample.]] {{Main|Fasciolosis}}A diagnosis may be made by finding yellow-brown eggs in the stool. They are indistinguishable from the eggs of ''[[Fascioloides magna]]'', although the eggs of ''F. magna'' are very rarely passed in sheep, goats, or cattle. If a patient has eaten infected liver, and the eggs pass through the body and out via the faeces, a false positive result to the test can occur. Daily examination during a liver-free diet will unmask this false diagnosis.<ref name="ValeroPerez-Crespo2009">{{cite journal|last1=Valero|first1=M. Adela|last2=Perez-Crespo|first2=Ignacio|last3=Periago|first3=M. Victoria|last4=Khoubbane|first4=Messaoud|last5=Mas-Coma|first5=Santiago|title=Fluke egg characteristics for the diagnosis of human and animal fascioliasis by Fasciola hepatica and F. gigantica|journal=Acta Tropica|volume=111|issue=2|year=2009|pages=150–159|issn=0001-706X|doi=10.1016/j.actatropica.2009.04.005|pmid=19375410}}</ref>
An [[ELISA|enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test]] is the diagnostic test of choice. ELISA is available commercially and can detect antihepatica [[antibody|antibodies]] in serum and milk; new tests intended for use on faecal samples are being developed.<ref name="MezoGonzález-Warleta2004">{{cite journal|last1=Mezo|first1=Mercedes|last2=González-Warleta|first2=Marta|last3=Carro|first3=Carmen|last4=Ubeira|first4=Florencio M.|title=AN ULTRASENSITIVE CAPTURE ELISA FOR DETECTION OF FASCIOLA HEPATICA COPROANTIGENS IN SHEEP AND CATTLE USING A NEW MONOCLONAL ANTIBODY (MM3)|journal=Journal of Parasitology|volume=90|issue=4|year=2004|pages=845–852|issn=0022-3395|doi=10.1645/GE-192R|pmid=15357080}}</ref> Using ELISA is more specific than using a [[Western blot]] or Arc2 [[immunodiffusion]].<ref name=gorgasmarch/> [[Protease]]s secreted by ''F. hepatica'' have been used experimentally in immunizing antigens.<ref name="CornelissenGaasenbeek2001">{{cite journal|last1=Cornelissen|first1=Jan B.W.J.|last2=Gaasenbeek|first2=Cor P.H.|last3=Borgsteede|first3=Fred H.M|last4=Holland|first4=Wicher G|last5=Harmsen|first5=Michiel M|last6=Boersma|first6=Wim J.A|title=Early immunodiagnosis of fasciolosis in ruminants using recombinant Fasciola hepatica cathepsin L-like protease|journal=International Journal for Parasitology|volume=31|issue=7|year=2001|pages=728–737|issn=0020-7519|doi=10.1016/S0020-7519(01)00175-8}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of parasites (human)]] *[[Veterinary parasitology]] *[[Trematoda]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox non-profit | name = | image = Five and Alive logo.jpg | image_size = 180px | type = International Development
Relief Services | founded_date = 2007 | tax_id = 56-0942853{{cite web|url=http://www2.guidestar.org/PartnerReport.aspx?Partner=networkforgood&ein=56-0942853 |title=NetWorkForGood-Organization Report |publisher=GuideStar |date=2010-10-26 |accessdate=2011-08-25}} | registration_id = | founder = [[Kate Roberts (YouthAIDS)|Kate Roberts]] | location = [[Washington D.C.]] | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = [[Kate Roberts (YouthAIDS)|Kate Roberts]]; [[Karl W. Hofmann]] | area_served = global | product = | mission = The mission of PSI is to measurably improve the health of poor and vulnerable people in the developing world, principally through social marketing of family planning and health products and services, and health communications. Social marketing engages private sector resources and uses private sector techniques to encourage healthy behavior and make markets work for the poor. | focus = children under five years old | method = | revenue = $417,470,056 ({{As of|2008}}) | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 101–500 | num_members = | subsid = | opponents = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|psi.org/five-alive}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Five & Alive''' is an international fundraising and awareness initiative of [[Population Services International]] (PSI), which addresses health crises facing children under the age of five and their families. The program addresses health issues in children in over 30 countries worldwide,{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mandy-moore |title=Mandy Moore |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18}} focusing on educating the public of deadly, yet preventable diseases, including [[malaria]], [[water-borne illness]], [[pneumonia]], [[micronutrients]], and [[malnutrition]]. {{As of|2012}}, the program has purified over 40 billion liters of water and distributed more than 50 million mosquito nets to underprivileged children and their families all over the world.{{cite web|url=http://aspenpeak-magazine.com/personalities/articles/graceful-glamour |title=Molly Sims' Graceful Glamour :: Articles |publisher=Aspen Peak Magazine |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/13040?pageNumber=2 |title=Five & Alive Stories : World Savers Awards : Condé Nast Traveler |publisher=Concierge.com |date=2008-08-19 |accessdate=2012-05-18}} Five & Alive collaborates with strategic partners to raise awareness of the effects of malaria specifically on children under the age of five. Global Ambassadors for the program include [[Ashley Judd]],{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/ga/president/62/ThematicDebates/humantrafficking/ashleyspeech.pdf |title=Ashley Judd Speech to the United Nations |publisher=Un.org |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18}}{{cite web |url=http://kinshasa.usembassy.gov/pr050108.html |title=May 1, 2008: Acclaimed Actress and Activist Ashley Judd Visits the DRC - Embassy of the United States - Kinshasa, Congo |publisher=Kinshasa.usembassy.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930030816/http://kinshasa.usembassy.gov/pr050108.html |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |df= }} [[Molly Sims]],{{cite web|url=http://vegasmagazine.com/celebrities/articles/sims-city |title=Molly Sims: Worker in Progress :: Articles |publisher=Vegas Magazine |date= |accessdate=2011-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://aspenpeak-magazine.com/celebrities/articles/graceful-glamour |title=Molly Sims' Graceful Glamour :: Articles |publisher=Aspen Peak Magazine |date= |accessdate=2011-10-22}} [[Anna Kournikova]],{{cite web |url=http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/blogs/80days/2009/02/day-one-child-s.html |title=Anna Kournikova in Haiti, Day One: Child Survival - The Daily Traveler |publisher=Concierge.com |date=2009-02-27 |accessdate=2011-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020112223/http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/blogs/80days/2009/02/day-one-child-s.html# |archive-date=2011-10-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and [[Mandy Moore]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ventertainmentonline.com/Mandy-Moore.htm |title=Mandy Moore |publisher=Ventertainmentonline.com |date=2009-02-11 |accessdate=2011-08-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110918230545/http://www.ventertainmentonline.com/Mandy-Moore.htm# |archive-date=2011-09-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == Organizational overview == Five & Alive was established by [[Kate Roberts (YouthAIDS)|Kate Roberts]] in 2007, as a subsidiary program of Population Services International, where she serves as Vice President of Corporate Marketing and Communications. The health program is a collaborative initiative of [[YouthAIDS]], an HIV/AIDS education and prevention program of PSI. YouthAIDS and Five & Alive serve to increase awareness of health crises primarily facing the [[Africa]]n continent, the [[Global South]] and developing world, while providing practical support and programming to save the lives of poor and vulnerable children.{{cite web|url=http://www.looktothestars.org/charity/1234-five-and-alive |title=Five & Alive: Celebrity Supporters |publisher=Looktothestars.org |date= |accessdate=2011-08-25}} Five & Alive is an awareness, marketing and fundraising campaign of PSI that focuses on the global health crisis facing children under the age of five and their families. The program provides the education, resources, products, and care necessary for children and their families to fight off entirely preventable death and disease. Using targeted subsidies and free distribution, PSI offers long-lasting [[mosquito net]]s and [[Malaria#Treatment|malaria treatment]], pneumonia [[antibiotics]] and [[antimalarial medication]], [[micronutrients]], [[rehydration salts]], and [[water purification tablets]], including WhuaAgar and PUR for individuals determined to be among those at the greatest risk for health crisis and death.{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/five-alive |title=Five & Alive |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501045742/http://www.psi.org/five-alive |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }} Every year, malaria infects between 350–500 million lives, leading to over a million deaths, primarily in children located on the African continent. At the same time, pneumonia has globally been the leading cause of death in children under the age of five years.
All children, no matter where they are born, deserve a healthy start in life. Nearly 11 million children die before their fifth birthday and the majority of these deaths are preventable.{{cite web |url=http://ashley-judd.com/site/archive/april-2007/ |title=April 2007 |publisher=ashley-judd.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110518235837/http://ashley-judd.com/site/archive/april-2007/ |archivedate=2011-05-18 |df= }} –Ashley Judd, Five & Alive Global Ambassador
== Key program areas == [[File:Mosquito Netting.jpg|thumb|220px|Mosquito net attached to the ceiling]] === Diarrheal disease treatment and prevention === Five & Alive promotes safe drinking water through household [[water treatment]], a water-quality intervention that employs proven, easy-to-use and inexpensive solutions appropriate for the developing world. Five & Alive improves the lives of individuals around the world by ensuring that household water is clean and safe, regardless of its source. Five & Alive's water-treatment products include a [[sodium hypochlorite]]-based safe water solution, [[Portable water purification|chlorine-based tablets]] and a [[flocculation|flocculent]]/[[disinfectant]] powder that enable families to purify water at the household level.{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/diarrheal-disease?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |title=Diarrheal Disease |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501150012/http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/diarrheal-disease?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }} The availability of these products, along with effective communications, empowers individuals to understand the burden that contaminated drinking water has on their health and allows them to take solutions into their own hands. Using both commercial marketing channels and community mobilization, Five & Alive generates awareness about the value of disinfecting drinking water, hand washing and other key hygiene behaviors. Five & Alive complements its work in safe water with the promotion of [[oral rehydration salt]]s (ORS) and zinc supplements to save the lives of children who may die from [[diarrhea]]-related [[dehydration]]. These child deaths are easily preventable, yet the lack of widespread knowledge and improved practices continue to present many challenges. Five & Alive's diarrheal disease treatment programs educate caregivers on the use of ORS and zinc and expand the availability of these life-saving products through commercial and other non-traditional channels. As identified by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), the integration of dissolvable zinc tablets enhances the ability of mothers and caregivers to understand and easily treat future episodes of diarrhea, which can save the lives of their children. === Pneumonia treatment === [[Pneumonia]] is the second leading cause of death among children under five. Early diagnosis and treatment with simple [[antibiotics]] can prevent a large proportion of these deaths. A severe form of [[acute respiratory infection]], pneumonia can be treated effectively using Five & Alive's pre-packaged therapy kits that contain [[cotrimoxazole]] and are easy to administer. Combined with comprehensive communications, this treatment is currently provided through private sector clinics to treat pneumonia in children under five.{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/pneumonia?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |title=Pneumonia |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501150627/http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/pneumonia?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }} === Malnutrition treatment === Five & Alive estimates that over 3.5 million deaths of mothers and children have occurred due to [[malnutrition]], or "undernutrition". They attribute the cause resulting from a variety of factors, including [[poverty]], [[chronic illness]], inadequate access to health services, insufficient [[macronutrient|macro]] and [[micronutrient]] intake, unsafe water, and lack of access to improved sanitation. For young children, ensuring access to health and nutritional sustenance during the first 1,000 days from conception to age two, can break the cycle of malnutrition. The treatment program offered by the organization is cost-effective, when appropriately tailored and applied during the first two years of life.{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/undernutrition?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |title=Undernutrition |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18 }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=Yeenosaurus |fix-attempted=yes }} The programming efforts launched by Five & Alive are proven successful, based on best-practices and evidence-based nutritional interventions, which include ensuring access to [[iron]], [[folic acid]], and multivitamin tablets for women of reproductive age, the promotion of exclusive breastfeeding, and large scale [[food fortification]]. Access to services are provided to women and children through community health workers, private sector providers as well as public health facilities. === Neonatal care === The death of children within the first 28 days of life, accounts for 41 percent of child mortality rates worldwide. Close to 50 percent of newborn mortality occurs within the first 48 hours of life. Coupled with minimal progress in reducing newborn mortality, a targeted effort is being made in order to make progress towards greatly reducing the mortality rate of children by the year 2015. In order to accomplish this, Five & Alive is focused on increasing demand and access to quality [[neonatal]] interventions. Provided services include ensuring access to [[immunization]] and [[vaccination]], and water and sanitation, all of which can be offered inexpensively, yet has consistently shown a high-[[return on investment]]. Additional services include improving access to a full range of basic education, primarily for young girls.{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/neonatal?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |title=Neonatal |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2012-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501150322/http://www.psi.org/our-work/healthy-lives/neonatal?phpMyAdmin=D673WcPmz30VmXaIcHmZXgbNRE3 |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }} Five & Alive readily promotes an integrated set of interventions that includes early initiation of exclusive [[breastfeeding]], [[Kangaroo care|kangaroo mother care]], delayed bathing, and early detection of infection, all of which are delivered by community health workers during home visits. The organization is also working to increase access to four percent [[Chlorhexidine]] (CHX), which is a simple and inexpensive antiseptic shown to reduce newborn mortality by 23 percent. This product is proven effective, when applied within the first 24 hours of birth. Five & Alive's health services includes clean delivery kits, [[antenatal]]-based services, private provider networks, and community-based distribution, all of which increasingly delivers consistent access to four percent CHX at scale. == Strategic partners == === Corporate support === Five & Alive works in collaboration with partners ranging from large corporations to celebrity ambassadors to other nonprofit organizations. A major partnership with ''[[Condé Nast Traveler|Condé Nast Traveler Magazine]]'' offers financial support through their Five & Alive Fund, in addition to comprehensive print coverage in support of Five & Alive's marketing campaigns, resulting in increased public awareness and funding.{{cite web|url=http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/12920?all=yes |title=The Week of (Not) Living Dangerously from Condé Nast Traveler on |publisher=Concierge.com |date=1994-04-06 |accessdate=2011-10-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/11352 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309003247/http://www.concierge.com/cntraveler/articles/11352 |archivedate=2009-03-09 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2011-10-22}} As a founding partner of the ''Condé Nast Traveler'' Five & Alive Fund, [[Crystal Cruises]] has raised over $180,000. Assistance has included the distribution of child survival packages in [[Uganda]]; and assistance in training community healthcare workers to provide free diagnoses and treatments to children in [[Cameroon]], resulting in an estimated 40 percent reduction in child mortality. The cruise line additionally provides opportunity for travelers to donate financially and purchase merchandise in their onboard retail shops, with all proceeds going to support Five & Alive.{{cite web|url=http://www.crystalcruises.com/support.aspx?FC=2&TPT=7 |title=Support |publisher=Crystal Cruises |date=2000-01-01 |accessdate=2011-10-22}} Partnerships with [[Blackberry Farm (Tennessee)|Blackberry Farm]] and [[The Inn at Little Washington]] have led to several fundraising events. Appetite for Life dinners at Blackberry Farm in 2009 and 2010 alone raised over $160,000{{cite web |url=http://www.psi.org/five-alive-news-media-and-events |title=Five & Alive News, Media and Events |publisher=PSI |date= |accessdate=2011-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111013125712/http://psi.org/five-alive-news-media-and-events |archivedate=2011-10-13 |df= }} towards Five & Alive's initiatives in Haiti, while events at the Inn at Little Washington raised over $650,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/04/01/AR2008040100603.html |title=Charity Gala to Mark Inn's 30th Anniversary |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date=2008-04-02 |accessdate=2011-10-22}} Other corporate partners such as [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Malaria No More]], [[Care2]], and [[Fortune Brands#Spirits|Beam Global Spirits & Wine]] have been vital in sustaining the program, ensuring the organization's timely response to global crises, free of restrictions on time and resource allocation required by more traditional donors. == Board members == * [[Frank E. Loy]], Chair – former [[Undersecretary of State for Global Affairs]] * Dr. Rehana Ahmed – Physician, [[reproductive health]] specialist for the [[United Nations Millennium Project]], [[Nairobi, Kenya]] * [[David E. Bloom]] – Chair, Department of Global Health and Population, [[Harvard School of Public Health]] * [[Barbara Bush (born 1981)|Barbara Bush]] – President, [[Global Health Corps]], New York * Sarah G. Epstein – Population Consultant, Washington, DC * Dr. Frans Engering – Diplomat (ret.), [[The Hague, Netherlands]] and former Ambassador to the [[Republic of South Africa]] * Shima Gyoh – Chairman, Nigerian Medical and Dental Council, [[Benue State, Nigeria]] * Gail M. Harmon – Corporate Attorney and Partner, Harmon, Curran, Spielberg & Eisenberg, LLP, Washington, DC * [[William Caldwell Harrop|William C. Harrop]] – former U.S. Ambassador to Guinea, Israel, Kenya, and Zaire; and Inspector General of the U.S. Department of State and the Foreign Service, Washington, DC * [[Judith Richards Hope]] – [[Adjunct Professor]], [[Georgetown University]]; Attorney, Washington, DC * [[Ashley Judd]] – Public Health and Human Rights Activist, Author, Actor, [[Franklin, Tennessee]] * Punam Keller – Professor, [[Tuck School of Business]] at Dartmouth, [[Hanover, New Hampshire]] * Dr. [[Gil Omenn|Gilbert Omenn]] – Professor of [[Internal Medicine]], [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] * Dr. [[Malcolm Potts]] – Chair, Population and Family Planning in the [[University of California, Berkeley School of Public Health]] * Bill Sanders – President, 400 Capital Management, Washington DC * Rebecca Van Dyck – Head of Consumer Marketing, [[Facebook]] == Further reading == * Judd, Ashley. ''All That Is Bitter & Sweet'', New York: Random House, 2011. {{ISBN|978-0345524829}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * {{YouTube|HealthyBehaviors|PSI and Five & Alive}} * [http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/bestoftv/2007/04/23/intv.roberts.ashley.judd.malaria.cnn CNN video: Global Ambassador Ashley Judd speaks about Five & Alive's malaria prevention programs] * [http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/26184891/vp/32967309#32967309 ''Today Show'' video: Global Ambassador Mandy Moore discusses her trip to Five & Alive programs in Sudan] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ItxoRxPisZs Global Ambassador Ashley Judd shows Secretary Albright how Five & Alive works in more than 30 countries to provide clean drinking water to those who need it most] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110927173449/http://www.marthastewart.com/show/the-martha-stewart-show/elle-macpherson?rsc=mphna_Homepage_Mostpopular_5 Martha Stewart pledges her support to Patrick O’Connell, chef and proprietor of The Inn at Little Washington, for their 30th Anniversary Celebration to benefit Five & Alive] {{DEFAULTSORT:Five and Alive}} [[Category:Health charities in the United States]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Washington, D.C.]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox skier <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Ski --> | name = Giusto Gervasutti | image = | fullname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1909|04|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Cervignano del Friuli]], [[Italy]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1946|09|16|1909|04|17|df=y}} | death_place = [[Mont Blanc du Tacul]] | height = | club = [[Ski Club Torino]] | skis = | personalbest = | seasons = | wins = | additionalpodiums = | totalpodiums = | medaltemplates = | show-medals = | updated = }} '''Giusto Gervasutti''' (17 April 1909 – 16 September 1946), was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[mountain climber]], [[Alpini]] officer and [[skier]].
==Biography== Gervasutti, also known as "Il Fortissimo" ("the hardest", "the roughest"), was born in [[Cervignano del Friuli]]. He started climbing at the age of 16 years. In 1931, he moved to [[Turin]] to study at the local [[University of Turin|university]].
Together with other well known climbers of the time he climbed the most difficult and sought-after faces in the Western Alps. His first notable success was the first repetition of Karl Brendelet's and Hermann Schaller's difficult climb on the south ridge route of the [[Aiguille Noire de Peuterey]] one year after them. Further he completed some first ascents of reliefs in the [[Dauphiné Alps]], for example the North West of the [[Pic d'Olan]] and the North West of the [[Ailefroide]]. During a visit in [[Chile]] in 1934, he climbed some five-thousanders. Also notable would be his ascent on the south west edge of the [[Picco Gugliermina]], which he mastered together with [[Gabriele Boccalatte]] in 1938. His masterpiece was the first ascent of the difficult east wall of the [[Grandes Jorasses]], together with [[Giuseppe Gagliardone]] in 1942, while he served as a military officer in [[World War II]].<ref name="alpinistidellambrusco">[http://www.alpinistidellambrusco.org/2012/02/storia-dellalpinismo-giusto-gervasutti.html Storia dell'alpinismo: Giusto Gervasutti] {{It icon}}, February 15, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.summitpost.org/giusto-gervasutti-english-version/178949 Giusto Gervasutti “il fortissimo” (1909-1946)]</ref>
Gervasutti was member of the [[Ski Club Torino]]. Due to an injury at the third [[Trofeo Mezzalama]] in 1935, he had to withdraw. [[Paula Wiesinger]], who was invited to view the race, took his military uniform, covered her face with sunglasses and his cap, and took part instead of him, but the cheat was discovered at a check point of the race.<ref>[http://www.fembio.org/biographie.php/frau/biographie/paula-wiesinger/ ''Paula Wiesinger''] {{De icon}}, FemBio.</ref>
==Death== Gervasutti died in a mountaineering accident on the [[Mont Blanc du Tacul]], when he was accompanied by Gagliardone. They were on the way back, because they had to abort the ascent on the north east wall, when the double rope pinched. During the attempt to set it free, Gervasutti fell headlong into a gap.<ref name="alpinistidellambrusco" /> The spur was named after him.
==References== <references />
==External links== * {{DNB portal|119036983|TYP=}} * [http://4sport.ua/articles.php?id=10581 История альпинизма в лицах: Giusto Gervasutti]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gervasutti, Giusto}} [[Category:People from Cervignano del Friuli]] [[Category:Italian military patrol (sport) runners]] [[Category:Italian mountain climbers]] [[Category:Mountaineering deaths]] [[Category:Sport deaths in Italy]] [[Category:Italian soldiers]] [[Category:Alpini]] [[Category:1909 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:People associated with the Matterhorn]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox website | logo = | logo_caption = Official logo of Indian Nursing Council | url = http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org/ | language = English }}The '''Indian Nursing Council''' is a national regulatory body for [[nursing|nurses]] and [[nurse education]] in [[India]]. It is an autonomous body under the [[Government of India]], [[Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India)|Ministry of Health & Family Welfare]], constituted by the Central Government under section 3(1) of the Indian Nursing Council Act, 1947 of [[Indian parliament]].<ref>http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org/pdf/inc-act-1947_New.pdf</ref> Since 1947 Indian Nursing Council Act has undergone minimal amendments. This resulted in several anomalies that have impacted the morale of Registered Nurses in India especially those practicing in the private sector. The last amendment of the act was in the year 2006. According to the original act the function of the council is to provide '''uniformity in nursing education'''.
== Functions of Indian Nursing Council <ref>http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org/pdf/inc-act-1947_New.pdf Functions of Indian Nursing Council <sup>Page 4,5,6,7</sup></ref> ==
* '''Recognition of nursing qualifications''' in India.<sup>(10.1)</sup> * '''Granting any nursing qualification''': Grants a qualification in general nursing, midwifery, health visiting or public health nursing.<sup>(10.2)</sup> * The Council may enter into negotiations with any authority [in any territory of India to which this Act does not extend or foreign country] which by the law of such territory or country is entrusted with the maintenance of a register of nurses midwives or health visitors; for the settling of a scheme of reciprocity for the recognition of nursing qualifications.<sup>(10.3)</sup> * Indian Nursing Council has the Power to require information as to courses of study and training and examinations.<sup>(12)</sup> * Inspect any institution recognized as a training institution, and to attend examinations held for the purpose of granting any recognized qualification or recognized higher qualification in India.<sup>(13)</sup> * '''Withdrawal of recognition'''<sup>(14)</sup>: The council may withdraw the recognition an institution recognized by a State Council for the training of nurses, midwives or health visitors does not satisfy the requirements of the Council. * '''Power to make regulations'''<sup>(16)</sup>. The Council may make regulations not inconsistent with the Indian Nursing Council Act generally to carry out the provisions of this Act, and in particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing powers.
== State-Level Nursing Councils == There are many registered state-level nursing councils.<ref name="councils">[http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org/pdf/snrc-State-Nursing-Registration-Council.pdf State-Wise Nursing Council] India Nursing Council, Retrieved on 29, October 2011.</ref> They are granted autonomous rights by the nursing council. {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+ |- ! Council Body !! State !! Year of Establishment |- |Andhra Pradesh Nurses & Midwives Council<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nmcouncil.ap.nic.in/|title=Andhra Pradesh Nurses ,Midwives ,Auxiliary Nurse-Midwives & Health Visitors Council|website=nmcouncil.ap.nic.in|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> |Andhra Pradesh |1963 |- |Arunachal Pradesh Nursing Council |Arunachal Pradesh | |- |Assam Nurses Midwives & Health Visitor Council<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://assamnursingcouncil.in/|title=Assam Nurses' Midwives' & Health Visitors' Council, Assam, Department of Health Services, Assam, Hengrabari, Guwahati, Assam, India.|website=assamnursingcouncil.in|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref> |Assam |1953 |- |Bihar Nurses Registration Council |Bihar | |- |Chhattisgarh Nursing Council |Chhattisgarh | |- |[[Kerala Nurses and Midwives Council]]||[[Kerala]]|| 1953 |- | Maharashtra Nursing Council ||[[Maharashtra]]|| |- | Delhi Nursing Council<ref>[http://www.delhinursingcouncil.com/]</ref>||[[New Delhi]]|| 1997 |- |Goa Nurs | |- |'''[[Punjab Nurses Registration Council]]'''|| Punjab || 2006 |- | Karnataka Nursing Council<ref>[http://www.ksnc.in/]</ref>||[[Karnataka]]|| 1961 |- | Uttar Pradesh Nurses & Midwives Council<ref>[http://www.upsmfac.org/]</ref>||[[Uttar Pradesh]]|| 1934 |- | Tamil Nadu Nurses And Midwives Council||[[Tamil Nadu]]|| 1926 |- |Rajasthan Nursing Council<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.rncjaipur.org/|title = Rajsthan Nursing Council|website = www.rncjaipur.org|access-date = 2016-04-14}}</ref> |[[Rajasthan]] |1964 |- |Madhya Pradesh Nurses Registration Council<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.mpnrc.org/|title = Madhya Pradesh Nurses Registration Council|website = www.mpnrc.org|access-date = 2016-04-14}}</ref> |[[Madhya Pradesh]] |1973 |}
==See also== {{Portal|Nursing}} * [[Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM)]] * [[Nursing in India]]
==References== {{Reflist}} <ref>http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org/pdf/inc-act-1947_New.pdf</ref>
==External links== *[http://www.indiannursingcouncil.org Official website]

revision.text:
The '''International Cancer Genome Consortium''' (ICGC) is a voluntary scientific organization that provides a forum for collaboration among the world's leading cancer and genomic researchers. The ICGC was launched in 2008 to coordinate large-scale [[Oncogenomics|cancer genome studies]] in tumours from 50 cancer types and/or subtypes that are of main importance across the globe.
Systematic studies of more than 25,000 cancer genomes at the [[Genomics|genomic]], [[Epigenomics|epigenomic]] and [[Transcriptomics|transcriptomic]] levels will reveal the repertoire of oncogenic mutations, uncover traces of the mutagenic influences, define clinically relevant subtypes for prognosis and therapeutic management, and enable the development of new cancer therapies.<ref name = "Hudson_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Hudson TJ, et al. | title = International network of cancer genome projects | journal = Nature | volume = 464 | pages = 993-8 | date = April 2010 | pmid = 20393554| doi= 10.1038/nature08987 | pmc = 2902243 }}</ref>
The ICGC incorporates data from [[The Cancer Genome Atlas]] (TCGA) and the Sanger Cancer Genome Project.
==Goals==
The ICGC is one of the most ambitious biomedical research efforts since the [[Human Genome Project]]. The consortium will help to coordinate current and future large-scale projects to understand the genomic changes involved in cancers of global concern. The catalogues produced by ICGC members will be made rapidly and freely available to qualified researchers, which will enable scientists around the globe to use the new information to develop better ways of diagnosing, treating and preventing many types of cancer.
The aim of the ICGC is to provide a comprehensive description of the somatic (non-inherited) genomic abnormalities present in the broad range of human tumors. Given our current knowledge of the heterogeneity of tumor types and subtypes, the ICGC set a goal of coordinating approximately 50 projects, each of which will generate the genomic analyses on approximately 500 cancer samples of each class. It is well recognized, however, that cancer is highly heterogeneous and hundreds of types/subtypes can be defined. Therefore, the stated goal of 50 ICGC projects is not intended to, and cannot, exhaustively cover the full spectrum of cancer types.
ICGC Funding and Research members proposing a project must agree to the ICGC’s policies, which include requirements for rapid data release, for rigorous quality standards and for protection of study participants.
The complete list of the ICGC Goals, Structure, Policies and Guidelines is available at http://icgc.org/
==Structure and funding==
ICGC is funded by participating nations, each of which focuses on one or more forms of cancer, with the goal of mapping the [[genome]]s of at least 50 types of cancer.<ref name="NIH">{{cite web |url=http://www.nih.gov/news/health/apr2008/nhgri-29.htm |title=Scientists Form International Cancer Genome Consortium |publisher=[[National Institutes of Health]] |date=2008-04-29 |accessdate=2008-04-29}}</ref> The consortium's secretariat is at the [[Ontario Institute for Cancer Research]] in [[Toronto]], Canada,<ref name="secretariat">{{cite web |url=http://healthzone.ca/health/article/419499 |title=Toronto-based consortium to seek cancer's genetic origins |last=Ogilvie |first=Megan |publisher=[[Toronto Star]] |date=2008-04-29 |accessdate=2008-04-29}}</ref> which will also operate the data coordination center. The provincial [[Government of Ontario]] provided funding of $40 million, and each participating funding member is expected to contribute $20 million toward each project. In 2009 the [[German Cancer Aid]] supported one ICGC-project with 7.9 million Euro. This was the highest amount a private organization gave. The money is donated by German people.
ICGC membership is open to all entities that agree to follow its principles and guidelines. The ICGC has received commitments from funding organizations in Asia, Australia, Europe and North America for 47 project teams in 15 jurisdictions to study over 21,000 tumor genomes. Projects that are currently funded are examining tumors affecting the bladder, blood, bone, brain, breast, cervix, colon, head and neck, kidney, liver, lung, oral cavity, ovary, pancreas, prostate, rectum, skin, soft tissues, stomach, thyroid and uterus. Over time, additional nations and organizations are anticipated to join the ICGC. The genomic analyses of tumors conducted by ICGC members in Australia and Canada (pancreatic cancer), China (gastric cancer), France (liver cancer), Germany (brain cancer), Japan (liver cancer), Spain (blood cancer), the UK (blood, breast, lung and skin cancer) and the USA (blood, brain, breast, colon, kidney, lung, ovarian, rectal, stomach and uterine cancer) are now available through the Data Coordination Center housed on the ICGC website at http://www.icgc.org. Data sets are browseable and may be downloaded at https://dcc.icgc.org/.
===Members of the executive committee===
*Australia: Warwick Anderson, [[National Health and Medical Research Council]] *Canada: [[Thomas J. Hudson|Thomas Hudson]], [[Ontario Institute for Cancer Research]], Susan Langlois, [[Prostate Cancer Canada]] and Cindy Bell, [[Genome Canada]] *China: Henry Yang and Youyong Lu, [[Chinese Cancer Genome Consortium]] *European Commission: Jacques Remacle, Patrik Kolar and Iiro Eerola *France: Fabien Calvo, [[Institut National du Cancer]] (INCa) *Germany: Axel Aretz and Frank Laplace, [[Federal Ministry of Education and Research]]. [[Gerd Nettekoven]], [[Deutsche Krebshilfe]] ([[German Cancer Aid]]), founded bei [[Mildred Scheel]], [[Bonn]] and [[Berlin]]. *India: M.K. Bhan and T.S. Rao, [[Ministry of Science & Technology]], Department of Biotechnology *Italy: Maria Cristina Falvella [[Italian Ministry of Education, University and Research (MIUR)]] and Giampaolo Tortora [[University of Verona]] *Japan: Sonoko Watanabe, [[RIKEN]], Tatsuhiro Shibata, [[National Cancer Center]] Sachiko Suematsu, Rie Tsuchida and Hideo Eno [[National Institute of Biomedical Innovation]] *Mexico: Miguel Betancourt [[Instituto Carlos Slim de la Salud]] *Saudi Arabia: [[Sultan bin Turki Al Sedairy]] [[King Faisal Specialist Hospital|King Faisal Specialist Hospital and Research Centre]] *South Korea: Hyung-Lae Kim [[National Center for Cancer Genomics, National Project for Personalized Genomic Medicine, South Korean Ministry of Health and Welfare]] *Spain: Elias Campo and Rosa Rodríguez Bernabé, [[Spanish Ministry of Science and Innovation]] *United Kingdom: Michael Dunn and [[Michael Stratton]], The [[Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute]] *United Kingdom: David Scott and Nic Jones, [[Cancer Research UK]] *United States: Jean Claude Zenklusen and Louis Staudt, [[National Cancer Institute]] Eric Green, and Carolyn Hutter, [[National Human Genome Research Institute]] Representatives with observer status: *Hong Kong: Joseph Lee, [[Hong Kong University of Science & Technology, China]]
== Current research projects == Each participating country has a particular tumor type as its primary research target:<ref>[http://icgc.org/files/icgc/NR_ICGC_March262009_en.pdf The International Cancer Genome Consortium announces the launch of 8 Cancer Genome Projects]</ref>
*Australia: [[Pancreatic Cancer - Ductal adenocarcinoma]] and Ovarian Cancer - Serous cystadenocarcinoma <ref>[http://www.oicr.on.ca/PDF/NR_ICGC_November182008English.pdf Australia National Health and Medical Research Council announcement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090323193624/http://www.oicr.on.ca/PDF/NR_ICGC_November182008English.pdf |date=2009-03-23 }}</ref> *Canada: [[Pancreatic Cancer - Ductal adenocarcinoma]] and [[Prostate Cancer - Adenocarcinoma]] *China: [[Gastric Cancer - Intestinal- and diffuse-type]] *[[European Union]]/France: [[Renal Cancer - Renal cell carcinoma (Focus on but not limited to clear cell subtype)]] *[[European Union]]/United Kingdom: [[Breast Cancer - ER+ve, HER2-ve]] *France: [[Breast Cancer - Subtype defined by an amplification of the HER2 gene]] *France: [[Liver Cancer - Hepatocellular carcinoma (Secondary to alcohol and adiposity)]] *Germany: [[Pediatric Brain Tumors - Medulloblasma & Pediatric Pilocytic Astrocytoma]] and [[Malignant Lymphoma]] and [[Prostate Cancer]]<ref>[http://www.icgc.org ICGC Project Website]</ref> *India: [[Oral Cancer - Gingivobuccal]] *Italy: [[Rare Pancreatic Tumors - Enteropancreatic endocrine tumors and rare pancreatic exocrine tumors]] *Japan: [[Liver Cancer - Hepatocellular carcinoma (Virus associated)]] *Spain: [[Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia - CLL with mutated and unmutated IgVH]] *United Kingdom: [[Breast Cancer - Triple Negative/lobular/other]] *United States: [[lung squamous cell carcinoma]], [[kidney papillary carcinoma]], [[clear cell kidney carcinoma]], [[breast ductal carcinoma]], [[renal cell carcinoma]], [[cervical cancer]] (squamous), [[colon adenocarcinoma]], [[stomach adenocarcinoma]], [[rectal carcinoma]], [[hepatocellular carcinoma]], Head and neck (oral) squamous cell carcinoma, [[thyroid carcinoma]], [[bladder urothelial carcinoma]] - nonpapillary, uterine corpus ([[endometrial carcinoma]]), [[pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma]], [[acute myeloid leukemia]], [[prostate adenocarcinoma]], [[lung adenocarcinoma]], [[cutaneous melanoma]], [[breast lobular carcinoma]] and [[Glioma|lower grade glioma]], [[Esophageal cancer|esophageal carcinoma]], [[Ovarian cancer|ovarian serous cystadenocarcinoma]], [[Squamous-cell carcinoma|lung squamous cell carcinoma]], [[adrenocortical carcinoma]], [[Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma|Diffuse Large B-cell lymphoma]], [[paraganglioma]] & [[pheochromocytoma]], [[cholangiocarcinoma]], [[Carcinosarcoma|uterine carcinosarcoma]], [[uveal melanoma]], [[thymoma]], [[sarcoma]], [[mesothelioma]], and [[Testicular cancer|testicular germ cell cancer.]]
== Future work ==
===ICGCmed=== Within the context of massive international sequencing efforts, and in anticipation of the new era of precision medicine, The [https://icgcmed.org/ International Cancer Genome Consortium for Medicine] (ICGCmed) will link the wealth of genomic data already amassed, as well as new genomic data being generated, to clinical and health information, including lifestyle, patient history, cancer diagnostic data, and response to and survival following to therapies, across the cancer spectrum. Using this large-scale integrated data, researchers, scientists, policymakers and clinicians will be able to work with patients, healthcare providers and others to develop preventative strategies, markers for early detection of disease, more specific criteria and methods for diagnoses and prognoses, and interventions based on matching the patient’s disease molecular subtype with the most effective combinations of therapies.
This will lead to the discovery of new therapeutic targets, more precise disease definitions and improved strategies to prevent drug resistance.
==See also== *[[The Cancer Genome Atlas]] - [[National Cancer Institute]] *[[Cancer Genome Project]] - [[Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cancer organizations]] [[Category:Medical research organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:Cancer genome consortium]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]]
