{{Public health}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Patient Safety Organization}} [[Category:Medical and health organizations]] [[Category:Patient safety]]

{{Tobacco}}
'''Prevalence of tobacco use''' is reported by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), which focuses on cigarette smoking due to reported data limitations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/whosis/indicators/compendium/2008/2ptu/en/ |title=Prevalence of current tobacco use among adults aged ≥ 15 years (percentage) |accessdate=2009-01-02 |format= |work= |publisher=World Health Organization |location= |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211143334/http://www.who.int/whosis/indicators/compendium/2008/2ptu/en/ |archivedate=December 11, 2008 }}</ref> [[Smoking]] has therefore been studied more extensively than any other form of consumption.<ref name="WHOMayoReport">{{Cite web | url=http://www.who.int/tobacco/resources/publications/mayo/en/index.html | title=Mayo report on addressing the worldwide tobacco epidemic through effective, evidence-based treatment | accessdate=2009-01-02 | work= | publisher=World Health Organization | location= | pages=2 | language= | doi= | quote=}}</ref>
Smoking is generally five times more prevalent among men than women;<ref name="HNPGuindonBoisclair13-16"/> however, the gender gap differs across countries and is smaller in younger age groups.<ref name="WomenTobaccoChallenges5-6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/tobacco/media/en/WomenMonograph.pdf|format=PDF|title=Women and the Tobacco Epidemic: Challenges for the 21st Century|accessdate=2009-01-02|author=The World Health Organization, and the Institute for Global Tobacco Control, Johns Hopkins School of Public Health|year=2001|publisher=World Health Organization|pages=5–6}}</ref><ref name="2001SurgeonGeneralWomen47">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/sgr/sgr_2001/sgr_women_chapters.htm |title=Surgeon General's Report—Women and Smoking |accessdate=2009-01-03 |year=2001 |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |page=47 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204062326/http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/sgr/sgr_2001/sgr_women_chapters.htm |archivedate=December 4, 2008 }}</ref> In developed countries smoking rates for men have peaked and have begun to decline, and also started to stall or decline for women.<ref>{{Cite book|first1=Richard|last1=Peto|first2=Alan D|last2=Lopez|first3=Jillian|last3=Boreham|first4=Michael|last4=Thun|title=Mortality from Smoking in Developed Countries 1950-2000: indirect estimates from national vital statistics|url=http://www.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/~tobacco/SMK_All_PAGES.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-03-22|year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=9|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050224232603/http://www.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/~tobacco/SMK_All_PAGES.pdf|archive-date=2005-02-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Smoking prevalence has changed little since the mid-1990s, before which time it declined in English-speaking countries due to the implementation of [[tobacco control]]. However, the number of smokers worldwide has increased from 721 million in 1980 to 967 million in 2012 and the number of cigarettes smoked increased from 4.96 trillion to 6.25 trillion due to population growth.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ng|first1=Marie|title=Smoking Prevalence and Cigarette Consumption in 187 Countries, 1980-2012|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|date=Jan 8, 2014|pages=183–192|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1812960|doi=10.1001/jama.2013.284692|volume=311|pmid=24399557}}</ref>
In Western countries, smoking is more prevalent among populations with [[mental disorder|mental health]] problems, with [[Alcoholism|alcohol]] and [[physical dependence|drug]] problems, among [[crime|criminal]]s, and among the [[Homelessness|homeless]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=West, Robert |author2=Shiffman, Saul |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Fast Facts: Smoking Cessation|publisher=Health Press Ltd.|year=2007|isbn=978-1-903734-98-8|pages=20, 26}}</ref>
In 2002, about 20% of young teens (aged 13–15) smoked worldwide. 80,000 to 100,000 children begin smoking every day. Half of those who begin smoking in [[adolescent]] years are projected to go on to smoke for 15 to 20 years.<ref name="WHO2002FactSheet">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/fact_sheets/fs_20020528.htm |title=WHO/WPRO-Smoking Statistics |accessdate=2009-01-01 |date=2002-05-28 |work= |publisher=World Health Organization Regional Office for the Western Pacific |location= |pages= |language= |doi= |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091108181404/http://www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/fact_sheets/fs_20020528.htm |archivedate=November 8, 2009 }}</ref>
The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) states that "Much of the disease burden and premature mortality attributable to tobacco use disproportionately affect the poor". Of the 1.22 billion smokers, 1 billion of them live in developing or transitional economies. Rates of smoking have leveled off or declined in the [[developed world]].<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 19910909 | year = 2009 | author1 = Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) | title = Cigarette smoking among adults and trends in smoking cessation - United States, 2008 | volume = 58 | issue = 44 | pages = 1227–1232 | journal = MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | url = https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5844a2.htm | format = Full free text }}</ref> In the [[developing world]], tobacco consumption is rising by 3.4% per year as of 2002.<ref name="WHO2002FactSheet"/>
The WHO in 2004 projected 58.8 million deaths to occur globally, from which 5.4 million are tobacco-attributed, and 4.9 million as of 2007.<ref name="WHO2007FactSheet">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/fact_sheets/fs_20070529.htm|title=WHO/WPRO-Tobacco Fact sheet|accessdate=2009-01-01|date=2007-05-29|publisher=World Health Organization Regional Office for the Western Pacific|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207100241/http://www.wpro.who.int/media_centre/fact_sheets/fs_20070529.htm|archivedate=2009-02-07|df=}}</ref> As of 2002, 70% of the deaths are in developing countries.<ref name="WHO2007FactSheet"/>
It is predicted that 1.5 to 1.9 billion people will be smokers in 2025.<ref name="HNPGuindonBoisclair13-16">{{Cite book|first1=G. Emmanuel |last1=Guindon |first2=David |last2=Boisclair |title=Past, current and future trends in tobacco use |url=http://www1.worldbank.org/tobacco/pdf/Guindon-Past,%20current-%20whole.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-03-22 |year=2003 |publisher=The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development / The World Bank |location=Washington DC |pages=13–16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318003729/http://www1.worldbank.org/tobacco/pdf/Guindon-Past,%20current-%20whole.pdf |archivedate=March 18, 2009 }}</ref>
== Countries ==
=== Australia === In Australia the incidence of smoking is in decline, with figures from the 2011-12 Australian Health Survey showing 18% of the population to be current smokers,<ref name="ABS Australian Health Survey 2011-12" >{{cite web|title=Table 7: Smoker status by age and sex, Australia|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/subscriber.nsf/log?openagent&43640do007_20112012.xls&4364.0.55.001&Data Cubes&2B9F30C81002A8C1CA257AA30014C2AA&0&2011-12&29.10.2012&Previous|work=Australian Health Survey: First Results, 2011-12|publisher=Australian Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref> a decline from 28% in 1989-90.<ref name="ABS Tobacco smoking 2007-08" >{{cite web|title=Tobacco Smoking in Australia, 2007–08|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/4841.0Chapter32011|work=Facts at your Fingertips: Health, 2011|publisher=Australian Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref>
Among the indigenous population, the rate was much higher: 50% of men and 44% of women reported being current smokers in 2007–08.<ref name="ABS Tobacco Smoking in Australia 2007-08 Table 2.1" >{{cite web|title=Tobacco Smoking in Australia 2007-08 Table 2.1|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/subscriber.nsf/log?openagent&tobacco smoking in australia.xls&4841.0&Data Cubes&F12AFAED1EDDA9B5CA25784F000D5DCE&0&2011&11.03.2011&Previous|work=Facts at your Fingertips: Health, 2011|publisher=Australian Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=19 February 2013}}</ref>
People aged 25 to 34 are the most likely to smoke (24%), with a marked decline in smoking rates as age increases past 45 years in 2011-12.<ref name="ABS Australian Health Survey 2011-12" />
In 2007–08, the prevalence of smoking was strongly associated with socioeconomic disadvantage: a greater proportion of men (33%) and women (26%) who live in the most disadvantaged 20% of areas were current smokers than those who live in the least disadvantaged 20% of areas (12% and 11% respectively).<ref name="ABS Tobacco smoking 2007-08" />
In 2016 the daily smoking rate is less than 13%.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-29/smoking-rates-at-record-lows-as-number-of-smokers-almost-halves/7886316|title=Smoking rates at 'all-time lows' in Australia|date=2016-09-28|language=en-AU|access-date=2016-09-28}}</ref>
=== Canada === In December 2002, [[Statistics Canada]] published a report on smoking prevalence from 1985-2001. In that report they found from 1985 to 1991, prevalence of "current smoking" (which they defined as daily smokers and occasional smokers) declined overall, for both sexes and all age groups except for those aged 15 to 24. Even larger declines occurred from 1991 to 2001. While current smoking prevalence for youths did not significantly change from 1985 to 1994-1995, there was a significant decrease of 6 percentage points from 1994-1995 to 2001 (from 28.5% to 22.5%). [[Province|Provincially]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[Quebec]], [[Ontario]], [[Saskatchewan]], [[Alberta]] and [[British Columbia]], experienced most of their declines in current smoking prevalence from 1994-1995 onwards. All of the provinces experienced some level of declines over the entire 1985 to 2001 period. Declines in daily smoking prevalence occurred for both sexes and all age groups over the entire 17-year time span, although youth smoking did not start significantly declining until the mid-1990s. Overall, for daily cigarette consumption, smokers by 2001 had a significantly lower proportion of smoking 26 or more cigarettes daily compared with 1985 (14.0% to 5.8%). Most of the declines in the different sex or age groups occurred after 1991. At the same time however, smokers in 2001 had a significantly higher proportion of smoking 1 to 10 cigarettes daily compared with 1985 (18.6% to 31.1%). Most of the decline occurred after 1991.<ref name="STATSCAN">[http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/82f0077x/82f0077x2001001-eng.pdf Report on Smoking in Canada 1985 to 2001], [[Statistics Canada]], Health Statistics Division, December 2002</ref> As of 2008 the rate was estimated to be 18%, and declining.<ref>http://www.cancer.ca/canada-wide/prevention/quit%20smoking/canadian%20tobacco%20stats.aspx?sc_lang=en</ref> A 2011 survey estimates that 17% of Canadians smoke.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/story/2011/09/07/smoking-rate-survey.html | work=CBC News | title=Smoking rate falls to 17% in Canada | date=2011-09-07}}</ref>
=== Germany === In 2005, 27% of the population admitted to being current smokers. 23% were regular smokers (28% of men and 19% of women,) while 4% smoked irregularly. The highest ratio of regular smokers was in the 20-24 age group: 38% of men and 30% of women.<ref name="mikrozensus">{{cite web|url=http://www.destatis.de/jetspeed/portal/cms/Sites/destatis/Internet/DE/Presse/pk/2006/Mikrozensus/Pressebroschuere,property=file.pdf|title=Leben in Deutschland. Haushalte, Familien und Gesundheit – Ergebnisse des Mikrozensus 2005|year=2005|publisher=Statistisches Bundesamt|pages=61–67|accessdate=2009-06-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419135952/http://www.destatis.de/jetspeed/portal/cms/Sites/destatis/Internet/DE/Presse/pk/2006/Mikrozensus/Pressebroschuere,property=file.pdf|archivedate=2009-04-19|df=}}</ref> According to a 2010 study by [[University of Bielefeld]], 9,9% of all 15-year-old males and 10,8% of 15-year-old females smoke daily, which shows a strong decline during the last decade.<ref>[http://hbsc-germany.de/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Faktenblatt_Rauchverhalten_final.pdf German youth smoking less]</ref>
Like in the most industrial countries the smoking rate in Germany decreases with increasing education level.
A 2006 comparative study found that 25.1% of male and 20.6% of female medical students in [[Göttingen]] smoke, while in [[London]] the ratios were only 10.9% and 9.1%.<ref name="raupach">{{cite journal|last=Raupach|first=T|author2=Shahab, Baetzing|year=2009|title=Medical students lack bacic knowledge about smoking: Findings from two European medical schools|journal=Nicotine & Tobacco Research}}</ref><ref>http://www.tabakkontrolle.de/pdf/Newsletter_April_2009.pdf{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Germany has the largest number of [[cigarette vending machines]] per capita in the world: 800,000 per 82 million people.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120306163217/https://www.facharzt.de/content/red.otx/191,2725,0.html?sID=6672fc2c0e2a7e879a1cb5efff9ea6fc Rauchen: Risikofaktor Nummer 1]</ref>
=== Israel === In Israel,<ref name="WHOISR">[http://www.who.int/infobase/reportviewer.aspx?rptcode=ALL&uncode=376&dm=8&surveycode=101391i4 Tobacco Use Introduction for Israel], [[World Health Organization]]</ref> smoking prevalence among males had remained relatively constant at 30% in the years 1994–2004.<ref name="Baron">{{cite journal | last1 = Baron-Epel | first1 = O. Haviv-Messika A. Tamir D. Nitzan-Kaluski D. Green M. | year = 2004 | title = Multiethnic differences in smoking in Israel: pooled analysis from three national surveys | url = | journal = European Journal of Public Health | volume = 14 | issue = 4| pages = 384–9 | doi=10.1093/eurpub/14.4.384}}</ref> Among females the prevalence has declined slightly from 25% in 1998 to 18% in 2003.<ref name="Baron"/> For the youth, 14% smoked at least once per week in a 2001 publication.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Meijer | first1 = B. Branski D. Kerem E. | year = 2001 | title = Ethnic differences in cigarette smoking among adolescents: a comparison of Jews and Arabs in Jerusalem | url = | journal = Israel Medical Association Journal: Imaj. | volume = 3 | issue = 7| pages = 504–7 }}</ref>
In 2005, research has shown that Israeli youths have begun to use [[bidis]] and [[hookah]], as alternative methods of tobacco use.<ref name="Baron"/> In 1990, smoking was the cause of about 1,800 male deaths in Israel which was around 12% of all male deaths.<ref name="CDCI"/> Smoking has not been found to be significant cause of death among Israeli women.<ref name="CDCI">[https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/WHO/israel.htm Tobacco or Health: A Global Status Report] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061210161042/http://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/who/israel.htm |date=2006-12-10 }}, [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC), accessed July 13, 2005 (site now down)</ref> The average number of cigarettes smoked per [[Israelis|Israeli]] stands at 2162 (6).<ref name="Baron"/>
There are several [[anti-tobacco use legislation]]s in effect. For instance, advertising is prohibited in youth publications and is forbidden on television and radio.<ref name="CDCI"/> in addition to substantial increases in tobacco taxes, although comparatively the prices are still among the lowest compared to all of the European countries.<ref name="CDCI"/> In addition, until 2004, there was no minimum age requirement for buying tobacco products in Israel,<ref>[http://www.euro.who.int/Document/E80607.pdf WHO European Country Profiles on Tobacco Control 2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100516083557/http://www.euro.who.int/Document/E80607.pdf |date=2010-05-16 }}, [[World Health Organization]], accessed November 24, 2005</ref> however, an amendment to the tobacco marketing and advertisement law that became effective at 2004 has limited the sale of tobacco to people above the age of 18.<ref>[http://www.moital.gov.il/NR/exeres/E13924CA-0B10-42C0-9F50-76F33C5E01CC.htm] [[Ministry of Economy (Israel)|Israeli Ministry of Commerce and Industry]]</ref>
According to [[Israel Central Bureau of Statistics]], the smoking rate in the Israeli adult population in 2009 was 20.9%, down from 34% in 2000.<ref>http://www.jpost.com/HealthAndSci-Tech/Health/Article.aspx?id=181972</ref> A Ministry of Health nationwide survey conducted in 2011 found that 20.6% of the population aged 21 and older were smokers.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Record Number of Non-Smokers|url=http://health.walla.co.il/?w=/5059/2537905|accessdate=15 June 2012|newspaper=Walla|date=31 May 2012|language=Hebrew|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604060437/http://health.walla.co.il/?w=%2F5059%2F2537905|archivedate=4 June 2012|df=}}</ref> The highest percentage of smokers was among Arab males, 44% percent of whom smoked, though this figure is down from 50% in 1996.
=== New Zealand === Tobacco consumption in New Zealand peaked in the mid-1970s when 60% of the population were smokers. By 2011 that number had fallen to 20% of the population, thanks to stringent tobacco control laws which are amongst the world's strictest. However, despite these laws, the number of smokers appears to be increasing as the global economy worsens and a recent spate of natural disasters have seen an increase in tobacco sales and although more males smoke than females, this gap is slowly narrowing. Tobacco consumption by [[Māori people|Maori]] remains disproportionately high despite having decreased over recent years thanks to television, internet, radio and print media anti-smoking advertising aimed at Maori. The high rate of Maori tobacco consumption has been described by many Maori health advocates and academics as a "cultural genocide".
=== Romania === According to the Romanian [[Ministry of Health (Romania)|Ministry of Health]], the smoking rate among the general population declined from 36% in 2004 to 26% in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.incont.ro/social/sanatatea-vrea-taxa-mai-mare-la-tutun-si-alcool-pentru-a-i-convinge-pe-fumatori-sa-renunte-la-tigari.html | title=Sanatatea vrea taxa mai mare la tutun si alcool, pentru a-i convinge pe fumatori sa renunte la acest viciu. Tigarile s-ar putea scumpi iar | date=23 December 2014 | accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> A report commissioned in 2012 revealed that 34.9% of men smoked daily, compared to 14.5% of women, and in the preceding 12 months, 37.8% of regular smokers had attempted to quit at least once.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.euractiv.ro/uniunea-europeana/articles%7CdisplayArticle/articleID_24085/Raport-4-85-milioane-de-romani-fumeaza-zilnic-sau-ocazional.-70-dintre-fumatori-isi-aprind-prima-tigara-imediat-dupa-trezire.html | title=Raport: 4,85 milioane de romani fumeaza zilnic sau ocazional. 70% dintre fumatori isi aprind prima tigara imediat dupa trezire | date=5 March 2012 | accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> Despite a general decline in smoking prevalence, the rate among women nearly doubled from 1991–2011, with 55% of women smokers belonging to the 15–34 age group.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ziare.com/viata-sanatoasa/fumat/una-din-cinci-romance-este-fumatoare-1115567 | title=Una din cinci romance este fumatoare | accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref>
=== Sweden === [[Image:Swedishtobacco.png|right|thumb|Swedish citizens, 16 years or older, that consumed [[snus]] or smoking tobacco on a daily basis in 2011.<ref name=scb01>{{cite web|title=Scb.se|url=http://www.scb.se/Pages/SSD/SSD_SelectVariables____340487.aspx?rxid=86a40219-57ef-4814-91e3-8247824582f6&px_tableid=ssd_extern%3aLE0101H25|accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref>]]
The first research of smoking habits in Sweden was performed in 1946; it showed that 50% of men, and 9% of women were smokers. In 1977 41% of men were and 32% of women smokers.<ref>http://www.nicorette.se/sites/nicorette_se/files/publication/Fakta%20om%20tobaksbruk%20i%20Sverige.pdf</ref> The use of smoking tobacco, on a daily basis, had in 2011 decreased to only 12.5% and 14.3% among women. The use of [[snus]], on a daily basis among men older than 15 years, was approximately 19.4% and only 3.0% for women.<ref name="scb01"/>
=== United Kingdom === {{Main|Smoking in the United Kingdom}} Figures from 2013 show that proportion of the British population (UK excluding Northern Ireland) who smoke has fallen to 19%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Release: Opinions and Lifestyle Survey, Adult Smoking Habits in Great Britain, 2013|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/ghs/opinions-and-lifestyle-survey/adult-smoking-habits-in-great-britain--2013/index.html|website=Office of National Statistics|accessdate=26 November 2014}}</ref> The Health Survey for England in 2002 found a smoking rate of 26%. By 2007 the proportion of adult smokers in England had declined four percentage points to 22%.<ref name=" The Information Centre for Health and Social Care">[:http://www.ic.nhs.uk/statistics-and-data-collections/health-and-lifestyles-related-surveys/health-survey-for-england/health-survey-for-england-2007-latest-trends-%5Bns%5D Health Survey for England 2007: Latest Trends], the [[Information Centre for Health and Social Care]], December 2008</ref> In 2015, it was reported smoking rates in England had fallen to only 16.9%, a record low.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-37406105|title=Smoking rates in England fall to lowest on record|date=20 September 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Overall, the numbers of smokers in the UK in 2007 was estimated at 13.7 million.<ref name="BJGPref">{{cite journal |vauthors=Simpson CR, Hippisley-Cox J, Sheikh A | title= Trends in the epidemiology of smoking recorded in UK general practice| journal=Br J Gen Pract |volume=60 |issue=572 |pages=e121–e127| year=2010| doi= 10.3399/bjgp10X483544 |pmid=20202355 |pmc=2828860}}</ref> The rate of smoking amongst the most socioeconomically affluent patients was 14% in 2007 and 34% for the most deprived.<ref name="BJGPref "/>
=== United States === [[File:Adult Smoking Prevalence by State US 2010.png|thumb|Smoking prevalence among U.S. adults by state (2010)]] [[File:US smoking percentages by gender, education, and poverty level.png|thumb|Smoking percentages by group in the U.S. (2010)]] [[File:CDC-chart-current cigarette use-1991-2007.png|thumb|Percentage of high-school students who reported current cigarette use (1991–2007)]]
According to the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]], as of 2015, a total of 15.1% of U.S. adults (16.7% of men and 13.6% of women) [[smoking|smoke]], which is down from 20.9% a decade earlier.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/adult_data/cig_smoking/|title=Smoking and Tobacco Use Fact Sheet|date=1 December 2015 |accessdate=30 December 2016|publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]}}</ref> Of U.S. smokers in 2005, 80.8% (or 36.5 million) smoked every day, and 19.2% (or 8.7 million) smoked some days. The prevalence of current cigarette smoking also varied substantially across population groups. For instance, current smoking was higher among men at 23.9% than women at 18.1%. This is consistent with other countries (see table). Among [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial]] and [[ethnic]] groups, [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] and [[Alaska Natives]] had the highest prevalence at 32.0%, followed by [[non-Hispanic whites]] at 21.9%, and non-Hispanic [[Black people|blacks]] at 21.5%. Hispanics at 16.2%, and Asians at 13.3% had the lowest rates.<ref name="CDC2005">[https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5542a1.htm Tobacco Use Among Adults: United States, 2005], [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], October 27, 2006</ref>
Smoking prevalence also based on education level, with the highest among adults who had earned a [[General Educational Development]] (GED) [[diploma]] at 43.2% and those with 9–11 years of education at 32.6%. Prevalence generally decreased with increasing education. Adults aged 18–24 years were at 24.4% and 25–44 years were at 24.1% had the highest prevalences. The prevalence of current smoking was higher among adults living below the [[poverty line]] at 29.9% than among those at or above the poverty line at 20.6%.<ref name="CDC2005"/>
In 2005, the CDC set a 2010 target of 12% for current cigarette smoking prevalence. Certain populations had already surpassed these when it was set. This included Hispanic (11.1%) and Asian (6.1%) women, women with [[undergraduate degree|undergraduate]] (9.6%) or [[graduate degree|graduate]] (7.4%) degrees, men with undergraduate (11.9%) or graduate (6.9%) degrees, men aged over 65 years (8.9%), and women aged over 65 years (8.3%).<ref name="CDC2005"/>
In 2013, the national smoking average in the United States was 19.6% of the adult population. The following have some of the lowest percentages of smokers with their states: * Utah, 10.6%, lowest percentage of smokers. * Hawaii, 14.6%, 3rd lowest. * Connecticut, 16%, 4th lowest. * Massachusetts, 16.4%, 7th lowest. * Vermont, 16.5%, 9th lowest.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Healthiest States in America|url=http://healthinformatics.uic.edu/infographics/10-healthiest-states-in-america-infographic/|website=University of Illinois at Chicago|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref>
Among cigarette smokers in 2005, an estimated 42.5% had stopped smoking for at least 1 day during the preceding 12 months because they were trying to quit. Among the estimated 42.5% (or 91.8 million) of people who had smoked at least 100 cigarettes during their lifetimes (the question the CDC asked to measure if they were ever smokers or not), 50.8% (or 46.5 million) did not smoke currently. In 2005, prevalence of current [[cigar]] smoking was 2.2% and current [[smokeless tobacco]] use was 2.3%. Prevalence of cigar smoking and use of smokeless tobacco were higher among men (4.3% and 4.5%, respectively) than women (0.3% and 0.2%).<ref name="CDC2005"/>
There are large regional differences in smoking rates, with Kentucky, West Virginia, Oklahoma and Mississippi topping the list, and Idaho, California and Utah at significantly lower rates.<ref>{{cite journal |author= |title=State-specific prevalence of cigarette smoking among adults and quitting among persons aged 18-35 years—United States, 2006 |journal=MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep |volume=56 |issue=38 |pages=993–6 |date=September 2007 |pmid=17898692 |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5638a2.htm |author1= Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)}}</ref>
Persons with mental illness, making up about 20% of the population, consume about 33% of the tobacco used. Persons with serious mental illness die 25 years earlier than average, often from smoking related illnesses.<ref name=NYT02613>{{cite news|title=Smoking, Once Used to Reward, Faces a Ban in Mental Hospitals|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/07/health/psychiatric-hospitals-alter-rules-on-patient-smoking.html|accessdate=February 7, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 6, 2013|author=Pam Belluck|quote=New data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that the nearly 46 million adults with mental illness have a smoking rate 70 percent higher than those without mental illness, and consume about a third of the cigarettes in the country, though they make up one-fifth of the adult population.}}</ref>
In November 2015, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and Prevention noted in their report, “The percentage of U.S. adults who smoke cigarettes declined from 20.9 percent in 2005 to 16.8 percent in 2014. Cigarette smoking was significantly lower in 2014 (16.8 percent) than in 2013 (17.8 percent).” The CDC concluded this from data obtained by a survey of Americans. However, researchers said that they are not sure if products like e-cigarettes are in any way helpful to reduce smokers in the country. Around 4,000 minors start smoking in the US every day.<ref name=MakadiaRoper2017>{{cite journal|last1=Makadia|first1=Luv D.|last2=Roper|first2=P. Jervey|last3=Andrews|first3=Jeannette O.|last4=Tingen|first4=Martha S.|title=Tobacco Use and Smoke Exposure in Children: New Trends, Harm, and Strategies to Improve Health Outcomes|journal=Current Allergy and Asthma Reports|volume=17|issue=8|year=2017|issn=1529-7322|doi=10.1007/s11882-017-0723-0|pmid=28741144}}</ref>

== 2008 data == {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Female Smoking by Country.png|image2=Male Smoking by Country.png|width=300|caption1=Percentage of '''females''' smoking any tobacco product|caption2=Percentage of '''males''' smoking any tobacco product. Note the difference between the two scales.<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, pp.267–288.</ref>}} <div style="clear:right; float:right; width:300px; border:1px solid #ccc; background:#f5f5f5; padding:5px;">'''Notes''' * ! Data were not validated by country focal point in time for publication of this report * * Current smoking prevalence not validated * In gray, data is not available</div>
The following is from the ''table b'' of ''WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic'' (2008).<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, pp.278–287.</ref> From the initial survey the data is adjusted making it comparable between countries.<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, p.67.</ref> Because of this, however, it is not for inferring the prevalence within those countries (''table a'' provides for this).<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, p.287.</ref> It contains 135 "Countries with recent internationally comparable adjusted data", 18 "Countries with national data that are neither recent nor comparable internationally", and 41 "Countries with no data".<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, p.68.</ref> The data represents smoking any tobacco product at the time of the survey including daily and non-daily smoking; the error is with a 95% [[confidence interval]] (CI).<ref>''[[#WHO2008MPOWER|WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic]]'' 2008, p.268–287.</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:Prevalence of Tobacco use}} [[Category:Smoking]] [[Category:Tobacco]]

'''Smoking in South Korea''' is similar to other [[developed countries]] in the [[OECD]], with a daily smoking rate of 19.9% in 2013 compared to 20.9% in Germany and 19.3% in Japan.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://data.oecd.org/healthrisk/daily-smokers.htm|title=Health risks - Daily smokers - OECD Data|work=oecd.org}}</ref> However, male smoking is among the highest at 36.2% while female smoking by far the lowest at 4.3%.<ref name="auto"/> The [[South Korean government]] aims to take down male smoking rate to the OECD average of 29% by 2020 by making the country one of the world's most difficult places to smoke,<ref>[http://thediplomat.com/2014/08/south-korea-no-longer-a-smokers-haven/ thediplomat.com] 2014/08</ref> using a combination of significant price hikes, mandatory warning photos on [[cigarette]] packs, [[tobacco advertising|advertising]] bans, financial incentives and medical help for quitting along with a complete smoking ban in public places including all bars, restaurants and cafes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newstomato.com/ReadNews.aspx?no=497194|title=10년만의 담뱃값 2000원 인상.."흡연률 29%로 낮추겠다"|work=newstomato.com}}</ref>
South Korea enforced strict [[smoking bans]] in public places since July 2013, with fines of ₩100,000 [[South Korean won|won]] on any spotted smoker and up to ₩5 million [[South Korean won|won]] on shop owners not following the law. It is illegal to smoke in all bars and restaurants, cafes, [[internet cafe]]s, government buildings, kindergartens, schools, universities, hospitals, youth facilities, libraries, children's playgrounds, private academies, subway or train stations and their platforms and underground pathways, large buildings, theaters, department stores or shopping malls, large hotels and highway rest areas. The strict bans came into force gradually beginning with a ban on places larger than 150 square meters in 2012, extended to 100 square meters in 2014, with a full-fledged complete nationwide ban on 1 January 2015.<ref name="New Year brings"> KIM BONG-MOON, [http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2999132 New Year brings in smoking ban] January 1, 2015</ref>
==Historical background== Smoking arrived in [[Korea]] in the early 1600s from [[Japan]]{{sfn|Lankov|2007|p=107}} and until around 1880, both men and women smoked.{{sfn|Lankov|2007|p=109}}
==Laws== Since 1 January 2015, South Korea has completely banned smoking on all bars, restaurants and cafes regardless of size, including any smoking rooms. Any spotted smoker must pay fines of 100,000 won and up to 5 million won on shop owners not obeying the law.<ref name="New Year brings"/> Anyone can report a smoker via calling or sending a [[text message]] to a government hotline (in the case of Seoul, the number is 120) with their location address and authorities will raid the reported place, of which a picture of the offending smoker will be taken and fined 100,000 won. Disguised authorities also secretly check random places at random times for offending smokers.
Since 1 January 2015, [[tobacco]] prices have nearly doubled to an average of ₩4,500 [[South Korean won|KRW]], and it is illegal to advertise misleading claims such as "light", "mild", "low tar" or "pure" on cigarette packs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-29154469|title=South Korea seeks near-doubling of cigarette price - BBC News|work=bbc.com}}</ref><ref>Newsis,. [http://www.newsis.com/ar_detail/view.html?ar_id=NISX20141231_0013387960&cID=10301&pID=10300 "새해 첫달 모든 음식점 금연 등 212개 법령 시행:: 공감언론 뉴시스통신사 ::"]. ''newsis.com''. </ref>
From December 2016, warning photos such as rotten teeth and black lungs will be mandatory on all cigarette packs.<ref>{{ko icon}} [http://www.joseilbo.com/news/htmls/2015/06/20150601259835.html 담뱃갑 경고그림 의무화, 13년만에 국회 통과] 조세일보 2015/06</ref>
Discussion is under way at the [[National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly]] to pass a law that will raise the prices every year pegged to [[inflation]].<ref>{{ko icon}} [http://news.kmib.co.kr/article/view.asp?arcid=0009003896&code=61111111&sid1=pol&cp=nv2 여권,물가 오른 만큼 담뱃값 올리겠다…흡연 억제 목적] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150107231459/http://news.kmib.co.kr/article/view.asp?arcid=0009003896&code=61111111&sid1=pol&cp=nv2 |date=2015-01-07 }} 2015-01-04</ref> The government will pass a law in 2015 to completely ban any form of advertising of cigarettes in convenience stores and make it illegal for tobacco companies to sponsor cultural or sport events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2015/01/12/2015011200212.html|title=편의점 內 '담배 광고' 금지… 올 상반기 法개정|work=chosun.com}}</ref>
=== Nationwide=== Smoking is illegal and strictly prohibited in the following premises:
* Office, multi-use or factory buildings larger than 1,000 square meters in floor area (of which offices, conference rooms, auditorium and lobby must be smoke-free). * Institutions larger than 1,000 square meters in floor area (of which classrooms, waiting rooms and lounges must be smoke-free). * Shopping malls, department stores and underground malls (of which any shop selling goods must be smoke-free). * Hotels and resorts (of which the lobby must be smoke-free). * Universities (of which lecture rooms, lounges, auditorium, cafeteria and conference hall must be smoke-free). * Indoor sports facilities such as basketball and volleyball courts which can seat more than 1,000 people (of which the seats and pathways must be smoke-free). * Social welfare facilities (of which the living and working rooms, lounge, cafeteria and conference hall must be smoke-free). * Airports, bus terminals and train stations (of which waiting rooms, domestic flights, cabins, inside trains, subway car and its platform and underground stations and underground pathways must be smoke-free). * Any vehicle that can seat more than 16 people. * Public baths (of which changing rooms and bathing rooms must be smoke-free). * Game arcades, comic book renting shops and internet cafes. * Bars, restaurants, cafes, fast food restaurants and bakeries, regardless of size. * Baseball or football/soccer stadiums which can seat more than 1,000 people (of which the seats and pathways must be smoke-free). * Kindergartens, primary and secondary schools. * Hospitals and health centers. * Nurseries. * Taxis.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2014/01/115_145662.html|title=No smoking in taxi|work=koreatimes.co.kr}}</ref>
===Seoul=== In addition to the nationwide ban laws, [[Seoul]] designates the following areas must be smoke-free and any spotted smoker must pay a fine of 100,000 won:<ref>http://blog.naver.com/inuri12?Redirect=Log&logNo=100159476243{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
* All subway station exits (10m around the exits) from April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mbn.mk.co.kr/pages/news/newsView.php?category=mbn00009&news_seq_no=2746291|title=지하철 입구 주변서 흡연하면 10만 원 과태료 문다|work=mk.co.kr}}</ref> * Subway station exits in [[Gwanak District]], [[Seocho District]] and [[Yeongdeungpo District]] (10m around the exits).<ref name="view.asiae.co.kr">{{cite web|url=http://view.asiae.co.kr/news/view.htm?idxno=2014123107172079817|title=서초구, 금연거리 연장 통해 금연구역 5500여 개소 늘어|work=asiae.co.kr}}</ref> * All parks owned by Seoul city (including sidewalks around rivers or streams). * All bus stops. * Apartments designated as smoke-free. * All gas stations. * Road between [[Gwanghwamun]] and [[Seoul Station]]. * Cheonggye plaza at the beginning of [[Cheongyecheon]] and [[Gwanghwamun]] plaza. * [[Insa-dong]] street.<ref name="news.hankooki.com">{{cite web|url=http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/society/201404/h2014040121013421950.htm |title=한국아이닷컴! |work=hankooki.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429050019/http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/society/201404/h2014040121013421950.htm |archivedate=2014-04-29 |df= }}</ref> * Both sides of the road between [[Gangnam Station]] and [[Sinnonhyeon Station]]. Extended to the road between Gangnam Station and Woosung Apartments in 2015.<ref name="view.asiae.co.kr"/> * The area surrounding [[Jamsil Station]] which includes [[Lotte World]], [[Lotte World Tower]], [[Songpa-gu]] Office, Galleria Palace apartments and entrance to Seokchon Lake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mt.co.kr/view/mtview.php?type=1&no=2014040908304060007&outlink=1|title=서울 송파구, 잠실역 사거리 금연구역 확대 - 머니투데이 뉴스|first=|last=MoneyToday|work=mt.co.kr}}</ref> * [[Namdaemun]] street around [[Myeong-dong]].<ref name="news.hankooki.com"/> * Both sides of the road between [[Yeouido Station]] and [[Yeouinaru Station]].<ref name="go.seoul.co.kr">{{cite web|url=http://go.seoul.co.kr/news/newsView.php?id=20140314027003|title=국회대로·여의도공원·영등포역 금연거리로|work=seoul.co.kr}}</ref> * [[Yeongdeungpo Station]] plaza and both sides of the [[National Assembly of South Korea|National Assembly]] road (2.1 km).<ref name="go.seoul.co.kr"/> * Both sides of the road around the [[Daechi-dong]] academy town.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0115_201308211357346971|title=서울 강남구, 금연구역 흡연시 과태료 부과|work=ytn.co.kr}}</ref> * Festivals street in [[Mok-dong]] around Happy department store.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://go.seoul.co.kr/news/newsView.php?id=20140418028016|title=양천구 금연교육 교실로|work=seoul.co.kr}}</ref> * Streets around the entrance of [[Hankuk University of Foreign Studies]] and [[Kyung Hee University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.unn.net/news/articleView.html?idxno=131028|title=대학가 금연거리 실효성 논란 - 한국대학신문|date=13 January 2014|work=unn.net}}</ref> * Seongbuk and Jeongneung streams, Hanaro street, Amazon street near Mia Elementary School.<ref>Newsis,. [http://www.newsis.com/ar_detail/view.html?ar_id=NISX20140402_0012828549&cID=10201&pID=10200 "성북구, 가로변버스정류소 금연구역 지정:: 공감언론 뉴시스통신사 ::"]. ''newsis.com''. </ref>
===Other regions=== In addition to the nationwide ban laws, several cities designate the following areas must be smoke-free: * Apartment corridors, stairs, elevators and car parks in [[Gyeonggi-do]] if at least 60% of residents have agreed to keep them smoke-free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.donga.com/3/all/20150223/69745415/1|title=[수도권]경기도의회 “아파트 복도-계단도 금연구역으로”|work=donga.com}}</ref> * [[Wolmi-do]] culture street in [[Incheon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.itimes.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=517993|title=월미도 문화의 거리 '금연거리 말뿐'|work=itimes.co.kr}}</ref> * All bus stops, areas around schools, Lake Park and Hwarang pleasure ground in [[Ansan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajunews.com/view/20140304093716641|title=안산시 공공장소 금연 홍보 캠페인 전개|work=ajunews.com}}</ref> * All bus stops, areas around schools and city parks in [[Seongnam]].<ref>http://news1.kr/articles/1479624</ref> * The entire [[Busan]] Citizens' Park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hkbs.co.kr/?m=bbs&bid=local4&uid=299053|title=5월 1일 개장을 앞둔 부산시민공원 금연구역 지정|first=|last=www.hkbs.co.kr|work=hkbs.co.kr}}</ref> * Dongseong street in [[Daegu]].<ref>http://www.imaeil.com/sub_news/sub_news_view.php?news_id=12735&yy=2014</ref> * Noeun Station and Yuseong Culture Park in [[Daejeon]]'s [[Yuseong District]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daejonilbo.com/news/newsitem.asp?pk_no=1108818|title=대전일보 :: 대전 유성구 금연거리 조성|work=daejonilbo.com}}</ref> * [[Sanbon]] Rodeo Street in [[Gunpo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anewsa.com/detail.php?number=775412&thread=09r02|title=군포, 중심상업지역 주요 보도 금연구역 지정|work=anewsa.com}}</ref>
==Financial and medical help for quitting==
People who have successfully quit smoking will receive 50,000 to 150,000 KRW as a financial incentive from the government. A 12-week medical help program for quitting is provided at a heavily subsidised cost of 5,000KRW upon the first treatment, reduced to 3,000KRW thereafter. Smoking cessation aids such as [[bupropion]], [[varenicline]] and nicotin patches are handed out for free at any participating medical center nationwide. Anyone in need of consulting smoking cessation can dial a hotline and consult a doctor or specialist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news1.kr/articles/?2049574|title=대통령 한마디에…복지부 "금연 성공땐 인센티브 5만~10만원"|date=16 January 2015|work=news1.kr}}</ref>
Residents of [[Seoul]]'s [[Seocho District]] will receive a 5 million KRW cash prize if they have successfully quit smoking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://view.asiae.co.kr/news/view.htm?idxno=2015011909082117345|title=[르포]담뱃값 인상 20일째…'한 대에 무너져요'|work=asiae.co.kr}}</ref>
==Prevalence and effects== Reports suggest that persistently high rates of smoking in [[military of South Korea|the military]] contribute to the high incidence of male smoking, and negate the efficacy of anti-smoking measures, as many men start smoking during their [[Conscription|mandatory]] 2-year [[military of South Korea|military service]]. The Public Health Graduate School of [[Yonsei University]] completed a 13-year medical study on 1.2 million patients and found that about 73% of male smokers and 18% of female smokers contracted [[lung cancer]].{{Citation needed|reason=Very unlikely; unable to find a study supporting those numbers|date=March 2014}} There is rising awareness of the [[health effects of tobacco]].<ref name="euromonitor">{{cite web | url= http://www.euromonitor.com/Tobacco_in_South_Korea | title= Tobacco in South Korea | publisher= euromonitor | date= Aug 2010 | accessdate = 2011 }}</ref> The [[economy of South Korea]] loses more than 10 trillion ''[[South Korean won|won]]'' a year in terms of health-care expenses and lost man-hours due to smoking-related illness.{{cn|date=September 2015}}
Eight out of ten teenagers were found to think they should not smoke by looking at cigarette pack warning pictures. According to the Center for Disease Control, 83.1% of teenagers who know cigarette warning pictures responded that they thought smoking cigarettes should not be allowed to smoke. The health authorities have announced that they will replace the cigarette warning label in December and will include a picture symbolizing 'carcinogenicity' in cigarette-type electronic cigarette packs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ggilbo.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=513975|title=Smoking cigarette warning picture, prevention of smoking in 83% of youth|last=주|first=홍철|date=2018-06-01|work=금강일보|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref>
==South Korean smoking etiquette== Local smoking [[Etiquette in South Korea|etiquette]] in South Korea is influenced by [[Korean Confucianism|Confucianism]]. For instance, smokers generally refrain from, or seek permission before lighting up in the presence of social superiors;<ref name="James Turnbull part 1">{{cite web | url= http://koreabridge.net/post/gender-politics-smoking-south-korea-part-1-james-turnbull | title= The Gender Politics of Smoking in South Korea: Part 1 | last= Turnbull | first= James | publisher= koreabridge | date= 2010-06-06 | accessdate = }}</ref> a social superior could be a boss, professor, parent, grandparent, or teacher.
==See also== {{Portal|South Korea|Health and fitness}} *[[Smoking in North Korea]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} ===Works cited=== *{{cite book|last=Lankov|first=Andrei |title=North of the DMZ: Essays on Daily Life in North Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hmKiUkUE_p8C&pg=PA107|year=2007|publisher=McFarland|location=Jefferson|isbn=978-0-7864-5141-8|ref=harv}}
==External links== *Robert Neff [https://web.archive.org/web/20110430033535/http://www.rjkoehler.com/2010/06/01/korea-is-smoking-or-is-it/ Korea and “The World No-Tobacco Day”], June 1, 2010
{{-}} {{Smoking by country}} {{Korea topics}}

page.title: Social determinants of health in Mexico

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
'''Social determinants of health in Mexico''' are factors that influence the status of [[health]] among certain populations in [[Mexico]]. These factors consist of circumstances in which people grow, live, work, and age, as well as the systems put in place to deal with illnesses.
In Mexico, the health inequality among the population is influenced by such social factors. In the past decade, Mexico has witnessed immense progress within their health care system that has allowed for greater access to health care and a decrease in mortality rate, yet there are still various health inequalities caused by social factors.
[[File:Flag of Mexico.svg|thumb|Flag of Mexico]]
==Definitions==
[[Social determinants of health]] are useful when identifying risk factors that affect the health of an individual or group. [[Health]] is defined as "the overall condition of someone's body or mind".<ref>{{cite web|title=Health|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/health|accessdate=20 October 2013|author=Merriam-Webster.com}}</ref> As accessed by the World Health Organization, some major determinants of whether one is healthy or not include "the social and economic environment, the physical environment, and the person's individual characteristics and behaviours".<ref name=WHO2013>{{cite web|title=The determinants of health|url=http://www.who.int/hia/evidence/doh/en/|accessdate=19 October 2013|author=World Health Organization|year=2013}}</ref> Social determinants of health, as described by the [[World Health Organization]], include income and [[social status]], [[education]], social support networks, [[health services]], [[gender]], employment status and conditions, and race and ethnicity.<ref name=WHO2013/>
== Poverty == {{Main|Poverty in Mexico}}
In Mexico, poverty is reported using the [[Multidimensional Poverty Index]] and the [[Human Development Index]]. Together, these indicators suggest the overall poverty gradient of Mexico. The government’s social development agency reported a 0.6 percent drop of Mexico’s poverty rate from 2010 to 2012, but there are still 53.3 million people under the poverty line.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Luc|title=Mexico's poverty rate dips but little cheer for the needy: report|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/07/30/us-mexico-poverty-idUSBRE96T01F20130730|accessdate=19 October 2013|newspaper=Reuters|date=July 29, 2013}}</ref> A major effect of this poverty rate is the continuation of a huge wealth gap.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico has 'giant wealth divide'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/3953757.stm|accessdate=18 October 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=October 26, 2004|author=BBC News}}</ref> Although there is a huge gap between the top ten percent and the bottom ten percent, Mexico has seen an increase in the percentage of Mexicans who are within the middle-class category.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mexico’s middle class gaining from economic growth; Canada and the U.S. trailing |url=http://www.policyalternatives.ca/newsroom/news-releases/mexico%E2%80%99s-middle-class-gaining-economic-growth-canada-and-us-trailing|accessdate=20 October 2013|newspaper=Canadian Centre for Policy Alternatives News Releases|date=May 22, 2012|author=Canadian Centre for Policy Alternative}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=As Mexico claws toward prosperity, some in middle class slide back|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/as-mexico-claws-toward-prosperity-some-in-middle-class-slide-back/2012/12/19/93ecfe68-31c1-11e2-92f0-496af208bf23_story.html|accessdate=19 October 2013|newspaper=Washington Post|date=December 19, 2012|author=William Booth|author2=Nick Miroff}}</ref>
The poverty within Mexico can be separated into two categories: moderate and extreme. Both categories total to about 45.5 percent of the total population of 117.3 million people.<ref name=AnimalPolitico>{{cite news|title=1.4 millones de mexicanos dejan la pobreza extrema entre 2010 y 2012|url=http://www.animalpolitico.com/2013/07/hay-53-3-millones-de-pobres-en-mexico/#axzz2afm3acCw|accessdate=17 October 2013|newspaper=Animal Politico|date=July 29, 2013|author=Redaccion Animal Politico}}</ref> According to El Consejo Nacional de Evaluación de la Política de Desarrollo Social, also known as Coneval, there was a decrease in the percent of the Mexican population in extreme poverty, but an overall increase in the number of people that fall under the poverty line.<ref name=AnimalPolitico/> The study showed that the extreme poverty rate fell from 11.3 percent to 9.8 percent, while the moderate poverty rate increased from 34.8 percent to 35.6 percent.
The correlation between poverty and health can be described as a negative relationship in which as poverty increases, health decreases.<ref name=Mosley>{{cite journal|last=Mosley|first=W. Henry|author2=Lincoln C. Chen |title=An Analytical Framework for the Study of Child Survival in Developing Countries|journal=Population and Development Review|year=1984|volume=10|pages=25–45|publisher=Population Council|doi=10.2307/2807954 |jstor=2807954|pmc=2572391}}</ref> With a low income, families do not have the desired access to nutrition, resources, and health care as well as a means to reach these necessities.
==Gender==
[[Gender]] is a major factor that influences the health inequity hiamong the Mexican population. There’s a certain gender bias within general health and specific diseases. [[Gender inequality]] can be described as “the departure from parity in the representation of women and men in key dimensions of social life.”<ref name=Frias>{{cite web|last=Frias|first=Sonia|title=Measuring Structural Gender Equality in Mexico: A State Level Analysis|url=http://lib.scnu.edu.cn/ngw/ngw/xwbk/Measuring%20Structural%20Gender%20Equality%20in%20Mexico.pdf|publisher=Springer Science+Business Media B.V|accessdate=17 October 2013|year=2007}}</ref> In Mexico, [[machismo]] still affects many parts of the country and the effect that it has on gender roles in a patriarchal society. According to the [[World Health Organization]], a major step towards improving the overall health of the population would be [[gender empowerment]].<ref name=WHO>{{cite web|title=Closing the Gap in a Generation- Health equity through action and the social determinants of health|url=http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2008/9789241563703_eng.pdf|accessdate=19 October 2013|author=World Health Organization|location=Geneva: World Health Organization|year=2008}}</ref> According to the 2012 National Survey of Health and Nutrition (ENSANUT), 38 percent of Mexican women aged 20–29 suffer abuses at home with more than 34.9 percent in public.<ref>{{cite web|title=Encuesta Nacional de Salud y Nutricion: Resultados 2012|url=http://ensanut.insp.mx/informes/ENSANUT2012ResultadosNacionales.pdf|publisher=Instituto Nacional de Salud Pública|author=JP Gutiérrez|display-authors=etal}}</ref> With results like these, Mexico witnesses a huge gender bias that could explain major problems that emerge from within the household as well as those that partake in the work force. In the Mexican work force, women generally receive lower wages than men, even with educational levels taken into consideration.<ref name=Rhoda>{{cite web|last=Rhoda|first=Richard|title=Female quality of life in Mexico|url=http://www.mexconnect.com/articles/3577-female-quality-of-life-in-mexico|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> The median wage for female skilled technicians is 97.3 percent of what their male counterparts make, teachers with 97.6 percent, and female industrial supervisors make 68.4 percent of what males make in that same field.<ref name=Rhoda/> The gender inequity can be emphasized with the fact that there has not been "a female head of state and has had very few female cabinet members.”<ref name=Rhoda/> This explains the "26 percent of equality with men in the political sphere" and that of "42 percent within the economic and legal spheres."<ref name=Frias/> This gender inequality produces a gender bias that favors men. Women then lack the necessary access to resources such as medical care, transportation, and nutrition.<ref name=Mosley/>
==Education== {{Main|Education in Mexico}}
Level of educational attainment is a major determinant of health in Mexico. More education generally leads to increased income, better employment opportunities, and improved living conditions; these, in turn, lead to improved health.<ref name=WHO/> The educational system in Mexico has witnessed low enrollment as well as low student-achievement.<ref name=Santibanez>{{cite book|title=Education in Mexico: Challenges and Opportunities|year=2005|publisher=RAND Corporation|location=Santa Monica, CA|author=Santibanez, Lucrecia|author2=Georges Vernez |author3=Paula Razquin }}</ref> According to the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics, 99% of children are enrolled in pre-primary school.<ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web|title=Education (all levels) profile - Mexico|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/document.aspx?ReportId=121&IF_Language=eng&BR_Country=4840|accessdate=20 November 2013|author1=United Nations Educational, Scientific |author2=Cultural Organization}}</ref> Furthermore, 96% of girls and 95% of boys are in primary school.<ref name=UNESCO/> Evaluating data on secondary schools across the nation, only 69% of girls and 66% of boys are enrolled in secondary education.<ref name=UNESCO/> The data also shows that 28% of the population of tertiary age are in tertiary education.<ref name=UNESCO/>
The low enrollment can be correlated with the need for Mexican families to utilize all means to an income and having the whole family seek employment, even at a young age.<ref name=Santibanez/> A factor that can affect the low student-achievement is the matter of children lacking focus as a result of nutritional deprivation.<ref name=Santibanez/> Health indirectly influences education in the same way that education indirectly influences the health of an individual.
==Location== Location affects overall health and "chances of leading flourishing lives".<ref name=WHO/> Location affects the daily living conditions that people endure which in turn affects [[health equity]]. There are various differences between [[Urban areas|urban]] and [[Rural area|rural]] living conditions.<ref name=WHO/> According to the 2011 Latin American Report on Poverty and Inequality, over the past decade, both national and urban inequality have decreased, yet rural inequality has increased.<ref name=IFAD>{{cite book|last=IFAD|title=Poverty and Inequality: Latin American Report 2011|year=2012|publisher=IFAD|location=Santiago, Chile|isbn=978-956-9153-03-7|url=http://www.ifad.org/pub/pl/informe_e.pdf.}}</ref> [[World Bank]] data reports that about 61% of those living in rural areas live in extreme poverty.<ref name=IFAD/> The major causes for such social and economic gaps between these two sectors come from "a manifestation of spatially-differentiated patterns of economic development".<ref name=IFAD/><ref name=IFADFacts>{{cite book|last=IFAD|title=Rural poverty in Mexico|year=2012|publisher=IFAD|url=http://www.ifad.org/operations/projects/regions/pl/factsheet/mexico_e.pdf}}</ref> A major factor to such disparity is the "absence of rural development policy planning", especially because the "highest public spending on rural development benefits the country’s richest states".<ref name=IFAD/><ref name=IFADFacts/>
===Urban=== Urban areas seem to be overpopulated with almost one-third of the population living in four major metropolitan areas-20 million people living in [[Mexico City]] alone. This major urbanization represents the differences in living standards as well as access to health and social services. The lack of adequate housing within urbanized cities represents a major problem.
According to research conducted by the Office of Population Research from Princeton University, the main causes of mortality in rural areas are infectious diseases and malnutrition.<ref name=smith>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Kimberly|author2=Goldman, Noreen |title=Socioeconomic differences in health among older adults in Mexico|journal=Social Science & Medicine|date=October 2007|volume=65|issue=7|pages=1372–1385|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277953607002857|accessdate=4 November 2013|doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2007.05.023}}</ref> Moreover, chronic disease and other health problems associated with industrialization dominate mortality within urban areas.<ref name=smith/> A report from the World Health Organization states that about 32% of the total urban population in Latin America dwell in slums.<ref name=WHO/> [[Slum]]s do not provide the best access to sufficient living conditions. The same report details "the shift in population levels of weight towards obesity" due to nutrition transition that begins in cities.<ref name=WHO/>
===Rural=== Rural regions in Mexico comprise more than 80% of the land and house around 37 million people (36% of the population).<ref name="OECD 2007">{{cite book|last=OECD|title=OECD Rural Policy Reviews: Mexico 2007|year=2007|publisher=OECD Publishing|isbn=9789264011526}}</ref> These statistics confirm that Mexico is the country with "the largest population [that lives] in predominantly rural areas" within the [[OECD|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]].<ref name="OECD 2007"/> Additionally, the standards of living in rural populations are much lower than its urban counterpart and the gap is larger than OECD standards.<ref name="OECD 2007"/> The major drawbacks are the lack of good shelter, adequate drainage, and access to electricity.<ref name="OECD 2007"/> Within dispersed rural areas, about 68% of the houses had a solid floor, 52% had drainage, yet 87% had electricity.<ref name="OECD 2007"/>
== Steps for improvement == In the mid-1990s, the ''[[Secretaría de Desarrollo Social]]'' introduced the ''[[Oportunidades]]'' program (formerly known as PROGRESA), which is a multi-sector policy that brought upon [[conditional cash transfer]]s.<ref name="OECD 2007"/> ''Oportunidades'' dispenses money directly to poor households in return the families send their children to school, health services, and provide them with better nutrition by attending classes.<ref name="OECD 2007"/><ref name=Levy>{{cite book|last=Levy|first=Santiago|title=Progress Against Poverty: Sustaining Mexico's Progresa-Oportunidades|year=2006|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|isbn=9780815752219}}</ref><ref name=Rivera>{{cite journal|last=Rivera|first=JA|author2=D Sotres-Alvarez |title=Impact of the Mexican Program for Education, Health, and Nutrition (Progresa) on Rates of Growth and Anemia in Infants and Young Children: A Randomized Effectiveness Study|journal=JAMA|date=June 2004|volume=291|issue=21|doi=10.1001/jama.291.21.2563|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=198848|pages=2563–70|pmid=15173147}}</ref> Results from a study published in 2004 show that there have been improvements in overall health associated with better outcomes in child health, growth, and development.<ref name="OECD 2007"/><ref name=Levy/><ref name=Rivera/><ref name="Lancet CCTs">{{cite journal|last= Fernald|first=Lia C.H.|author2=Paul J Gertler |author3=Lynnette M Neufeld |title=Role of cash in conditional cash transfer programmes for child health, growth, and development: an analysis of Mexico's Oportunidades|journal=The Lancet|date=8 March 2008|volume=371|issue=9615|pages=828–837|url=http://www.who.int/management/country/mex/RoleofCashConditionalCashTransferMexicosOportunidades.pdf|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(08)60382-7|pmid=18328930|pmc=2779574}}</ref>
[[File:SEDESOL logo 2012.svg|thumb|SEDESOL logo 2012]]
In 2003, Mexico's Congress enacted reforms to Mexico's health legislation that aimed at making health care available nationwide.<ref name=Frenk>{{cite news|last=Frenk|first=Julio|title=The quest for universal health coverage: achieving social protection for all in Mexico|url=http://press.thelancet.com/mexicoupdate.pdf|accessdate=16 October 2013|newspaper=The Lancet|date=August 16, 2012}}</ref> Mexico's former Minister of Health, [[Julio Frenk]], as the original architect, implemented Seguro Popular which has insured 52.6 million previously-uninsured Mexicans.<ref name=Frenk/> With the implementation of this universal health care, more Mexicans can now access the health services in their community.<ref name=Frenk />
In 2008, the World Health Organization's Commission on Social Determinants of Health developed a plan of action to tackle the problems that social determinants of health have on health equity. The recommendations consist of "improving daily living conditions, tackle the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources, and measure and understand the problem and assess the impact of action."<ref name=WHO/>
== See also == * [[Health care in Mexico]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Mexico topics}}
[[Category:Health in Mexico]] [[Category:Determinants of health]]

{{More citations needed|date=May 2009}} '''Superfecundation''' is the fertilization of two or more [[ovum|ova]] from the same [[menstrual cycle|cycle]] by [[spermatozoon|sperm]] from separate acts of [[sexual intercourse]], which can lead to twin babies from two separate biological fathers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/3851843/twins-complications/?xid=time_socialflow_twitter|title=The Science of How Women Can Have Twins With 2 Different Fathers|first=Justin|last=Worland|date=May 8, 2015|work=Time|accessdate=March 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sogc.org/publications-resources/public-information-pamphlets.html?id=33|title=Public Education Pamphlets|work=sogc.org}}</ref> The term superfecundation is derived from [[fecundity|fecund]], meaning the ability to produce offspring. '''Heteropaternal superfecundation''' refers to the fertilization of two separate ova by two different fathers. '''Homopaternal superfecundation''' refers to the fertilization of two separate ova from the same father, leading to [[Twin#Dizygotic twins|fraternal twins]].<ref name=pmid10641935>{{cite journal |pmid=10641935 |year=2000 |author1=Ambach |first1=E |title=Superfecundation and dual paternity in a twin pregnancy ending with placental abruption |journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences |volume=45 |issue=1 |pages=181–3 |last2=Parson |first2=W |last3=Brezinka |first3=C }}</ref> While heteropaternal superfecundation is referred to as a form of atypical twinning, genetically, the twins are half siblings. Superfecundation, while rare, can occur through either separate occurrences of sexual intercourse or through artificial insemination.<ref name=pmid26548710>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.ajog.2015.10.930 |pmid=26548710 |title=A review of the mechanisms and evidence for typical and atypical twinning |journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology |volume=214 |issue=2 |pages=172–91 |year=2016 |last1=McNamara |first1=Helen C. |last2=Kane |first2=Stefan C. |last3=Craig |first3=Jeffrey M. |last4=Short |first4=Roger V. |last5=Umstad |first5=Mark P. }}</ref>
== Conception == Superfecundation most commonly happens within hours or days of the first instance of fertilization with ova released during the same cycle. The time window when eggs are able to be fertilized is small. Sperm cells can live inside a female's body for four to five days. Once ovulation occurs, the egg remains viable for 12–48 hours before it begins to disintegrate. Thus, the fertile period can span five to seven days.
[[Ovulation]] is usually suspended during [[pregnancy]] to prevent further ova becoming fertilized and to help increase the chances of a full-term pregnancy. However, if an ovum is released after the female was already impregnated when previously ovulating, a chance of a second pregnancy occurs, albeit at a different stage of development. This is known as [[superfetation]].
==Heteropaternal superfecundation in mammals== Heteropaternal superfecundation is common in animals such as cats and dogs. Stray dogs can produce litters in which every puppy has a different sire. Though rare in humans, cases have been documented. In one study on humans, the frequency was 2.4% among [[dizygotic twin]]s whose parents had been involved in [[paternity suit]]s.<ref name="suit">{{cite journal |pmid=1488855 |year=1992 |author1=Wenk |first1=R. E. |title=How frequent is heteropaternal superfecundation? |journal=Acta geneticae medicae et gemellologiae |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=43–7 |last2=Houtz |first2=T |last3=Brooks |first3=M |last4=Chiafari |first4=F. A. }}</ref>
==Cases in mythology== Greek mythology holds many cases of superfecundation: * [[Leda (mythology)|Leda]] lies with both her husband [[Tyndareus]] and [[Zeus]], the latter in the guise of a swan. Nine months later, she bares two daughters: [[Clytemnestra]] by Tyndareus and [[Helen of Troy|Helen]] by Zeus. This happens again, this time Leda bares two sons: [[Castor and Pollux |Castor by Tyndareus and Pollux by Zeus]].
* [[Alcmene]] is raped by Zeus, who is disguised as her husband [[Amphitryon]]; the real Amphitryon later sleeps with Alcmene and she gives birth to two sons: [[Iphicles]] by Amphitryon and [[Heracles]] by Zeus.
==Selected cases involving superfecundation==
In 1982, twins who were born with two different skin colors were discovered to be conceived as a result of heteropaternal superfecundation.<ref>https://www.scopus.com/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-0020008620&origin=inward&txGid=F6227767DB3CDB724EA92EFC60A5A985.wsnAw8kcdt7IPYLO0V48gA%3a2{{full citation needed|date=June 2017}}{{dead link|date=June 2017}}</ref><ref name=pmid26548710/>
In 1995, a young woman gave birth to [[diamniotic]] [[monochorionic]] twins, who were originally assumed to be monozygotic twins until a paternity suit led to a DNA test. This led to the discovery that the twins had different fathers.<ref name=pmid10641935/>
In 2001, a case of spontaneous monopaternal superfecundation was reported after a woman undergoing IVF treatments gave birth to quintuplets after only two embryos were implanted. Genetic testing supported that the twinning was not a result of the embryos splitting, and that all five boys shared the same father.<ref name=pmid26548710/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0015-0282(01)01976-8 |pmid=11532493 |title=Monopaternal superfecundation of quintuplets after transfer of two embryos in an in vitro fertilization cycle |journal=Fertility and Sterility |volume=76 |issue=3 |pages=621–3 |year=2001 |last1=Amsalem |first1=Hagai |last2=Tsvieli |first2=Rimona |last3=Zentner |first3=Bat Sheva |last4=Yagel |first4=Simcha |last5=Mitrani-Rosenbaum |first5=Stella |last6=Hurwitz |first6=Arye }}</ref>
In 2016, an IVF-implanted surrogate mother gave birth to two children: one genetically unrelated child from an implanted embryo, and a biological child from her own egg and her husband's sperm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/03/health/surrogate-mom-two-babies/index.html|title=Surrogate mom delivers two babies, one her own|publisher=CNN|date=November 3, 2017|author=Susan Scutti}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Chimera (genetics)]] * [[Mixed twins]] * [[Polyspermy]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{cite|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,520524,00.html |title=Doctors Discover Dallas Twins Have Two Different Dads|work=Fox News|year=2009|agency=Sky News}} * {{cite journal |pmid=8064269 |year=1994 |author1=Lu |first1=H. L. |title=Paternity identification in twins with different fathers |journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences |volume=39 |issue=4 |pages=1100–2 |last2=Wang |first2=C. X. |last3=Wu |first3=F. Q. |last4=Li |first4=J. J. }}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2012}} '''''The Bod Squad''''' was the collective title for a series of short public service announcements broadcast on Saturday mornings on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[television network]], from the 1974 through the first half of the 1990s. These thirty-second and one-minute segments promoted healthy [[nutrition]] and [[personal hygiene]] through humorous animation and catchy music with clever lyrics.
The segments generally appeared at half-hour intervals, interspersed with regular commercials, between [[Saturday morning cartoon]] programs. While many were not labeled as such, at least four or five segments ended with an announcement, "Another nutritional message from the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC Television Network]]," and accompanying stock animation identifying the series as ''The ABC Bod Squad''. The same original segments produced in the 1970s repeated every Saturday morning for nearly 20 years, so that many if not most Americans who were TV-watching children during that period are familiar with them.
The Bod Squad segments never carried official titles but are informally known by the catch phrases from their lyrics. Some of the memorable Bod Squad segments included
* '''Yuck Mouth''' and '''Nutty Gritty''' (both sung by actor/singer [[Scatman Crothers]]), * '''(Watch Out For) The Munchies''', about craving food when a person ''is not hungry,'' and * '''Quickfast''', suggesting pre-made or leftover foods for breakfast, or easily prepared foods such as toast, for children who are too young to fix meals themselves.
Some others not explicitly identified as Bod Squad segments but in the same vein were
* '''Don't Drown Your Food''' (voiced by actor/comedian [[Arnold Stang]]), encouraging children not to overuse condiments, such as gravy, ketchup and salad dressing, and learn to enjoy the natural flavors of vegetables, eggs, etc. * '''Make A Saturdae''', about using healthy foods — such as bananas and yogurt — to create "fun" snacks. * '''Zack Of All Trades''' (sung by [[Luther Vandross]]), a hip R&B singer teaches teenagers a valuable lesson about different types of careers. * '''Beans and Rice''', about complementary proteins, and combining basic foods to create new dishes. (Curiously, this short was performed by [[Jack Sheldon]] and [[Bob Dorough]], two of the major names behind ''[[Schoolhouse Rock!]]'', but was credited neither as a ''Schoolhouse Rock!'' short nor as a ''Bod Squad'' segment.)
Throughout the 1970s and 1980s ABC broadcast several other series of educational public service cartoon spots as well, including ''[[Time for Timer]]'' and, perhaps the most famous of all, ''[[Schoolhouse Rock!|Schoolhouse Rock]]''.
{{Children's programming on the American Broadcasting Company}}
